revision.comment: /* Job titles and job descriptions */
revision.text:
[[File:Game of Thrones - Klis Fortress, location scouting 2.jpg|thumb|The production team of ''[[Game of Thrones]]'' location scouting at [[Fortress of Klis|Klis Fortress]], Croatia.]] '''Location scouting''' is a vital process in the [[pre-production]] stage of [[filmmaking]] and [[commercial photography]].<ref name="LongSchenk2002">{{cite book |last1=Long |first1=Ben |last2=Schenk |first2=Sonja |title=The digital filmmaking handbook |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HVX4CcmjGSkC&pg=PA96 |accessdate=18 October 2010 |date=30 May 2002 |publisher=Cengage Learning |isbn=978-1-58450-098-8 |page=96}}</ref> Once [[scriptwriters]], [[Film producer|producers]] or [[Film director|directors]] have decided what general kind of scenery they require for the various parts of their work that is shot outside of the [[studio]], the search for a suitable place or "[[Filming location|location]]" outside the studio begins. '''Location scouts''' also look for generally spectacular or interesting locations beforehand, to have a database of locations in case of requests.<ref name="Markow1999">{{cite book |last=Markow |first=Paul |title=Professional Secrets of Advertising Photography |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WXgO8KWDYXwC&pg=PA19 |accessdate=18 October 2010 |year=1999 |publisher=Amherst Media, Inc |isbn=978-0-936262-79-6 |page=19}}</ref>
Location scouts often negotiate legal access to filming locations.
== Location requirements == Suitability of a location to the task at hand takes into consideration many factors, including: *overall [[aesthetic]] *financial cost to [[Film production|production]] *[[Logistics|logistic]] feasibility including but not limited to distance from base of operations or other locations scheduled *availability of parking and facilities to keep crew and talent (principal [[actor]]s or models and [[Extra (actor)|extras]]) safe and dry at all times *availability of electrical power or feasibility of bringing in generators for lights and electrical equipment. *available light (indoors or outdoors) and weather conditions (outdoors) *permission from and cooperation of location owner and neighbors, local government and law enforcement
==Work process== Typically ideas for what a [[filming location]] should or could be are discussed between production department and locations department (it could be at this point that the locations department is actually created), then research is begun to actually find and document that location using location scout(s).
The location scouts and other Locations Department staff (see below), working under the supervision of the [[Location Manager]], generally strive to provide as many potentially useful/viable ideas and/or options as possible for review by production; often the Assistant Director, Production Manager and subsequently, the Director or even the Executive Producer in the case of narrative filmmaking.
Once a consensus on locations with the most potential is reached, arrangements are normally made for some of the heads of the other Production Departments to tour those location(s) to confirm suitability. This tour is commonly called a "tech scout", "[http://dictionary.reference.com/search?r=2&q=reconnoiter recce]" or "go-see".
During this time the Locations Department (most likely the Location Manager in situations requiring the most responsibility) will have contacted and begun negotiation with internal and external parties that may affect ability to film at the location. This is known as "clearing the location": investigating and confirming availability and fees to be paid to a location owner or agent, obtaining a certificate of [[insurance]], obtaining any needed [[Filming_Permit|film permits]] (may involve fees). Also, there might be distribution of "resident letters" or "filming notifications". These are notices to neighbors, advising them of intent to film in the area (often a local requirement). These steps result in "locking down": making sure that all details and existing or potential issues are addressed. While it is the Locations Department's job to anticipate and minimize problems associated with a location, it is also the Locations Department's duty to advise other Production Department heads of intractable problems that need consideration so contingencies can be planned. This may lead to a decision to use an alternate location. This might involve additional planning and budget allocation for additional location scouting.
==Change management== Production events involving the Location Department and its personnel can occur very quickly and quite often, the requirements themselves, ''i.e.'', script rewrite(s), creative concept change(s), of a location itself can change [[on the fly]]. More often than not, multiple locations associated with multiple scenes in production are involved; under some circumstances, a busy and resourceful [[freelancer]] or Locations Department Staffer could be involved in multiple projects simultaneously.
==Problem solving== Solving location problems can be challenging, requiring hard work for long hours, keen [[communication skills]], focus, ability to "think on one's feet" or "[[Human multitasking|multitasking]]", take action quickly and responsibly as well as using technical skills. Familiarity with local resources and a network of capable support are needed.
==Booking a site== After completing all the steps above, if a location is still viable and available, it is confirmed (booked). Usually a contract is signed by all parties, and a property release is obtained: a written, signed permission from the property owner or agent allowing photography of and public depiction via media (''i.e.'', broadcast, video, film, print publication).
Once a location is booked, there are very few reasons for filming to not commence as planned. At this point many man-hours of paid production work and considerable amounts of money for location fees and/or permits have been invested in the chosen location. A change of creative concept at this stage or glitch of any kind (such as property owner cancellation) is potentially costly, and legal action is a possible consequence. Also, if production misrepresents itself regarding its activities, intended use of the location, damages the property or negligently causes other problems for the property owner, the property owner may seek remedy in any of many forms available, including legal action.
==Consideration of weather== Local weather conditions can figure heavily into a location's viability and affect many areas of production scheduling, so contingencies and alternate, budgetary-efficient plans should be made well in advance of any shoot day with a possibility to be affected by weather. A location with potential to be affected by weather should always be cleared and placed, in advance, with the property owner's understanding and consent "on weather hold" or under the condition that production will only confirm use of the location and commence photography pending viable weather conditions. The aim, in addition to the obvious goal of attaining the correct aesthetic for the shot in acceptable and safe working conditions is also geared toward providing greater flexibility of crew scheduling, equipment, vehicle, etc. rentals and other production aspects and minimize inconvenience to the owner and in the event of cancellation or postponement by production due to weather, eliminate or minimize cancellation fees as may be part of an agreement between production and the location.
==Locations for various media== In addition to [[feature films]] and [[short films]], [[television commercials]] and [[television shows]], [[documentary films]], [[corporate]] [[video]], [[Printing|print]] [[advertising]] [[photography]], [[editorial]] [[photography]] and even [[event planning]] all have the possibility to employ location scouts to find and photograph locations for their productions.
The methods employed are much the same as for feature film production, but the processes often differ in some ways:
Turn around times are generally shorter and the decision making is shared between production, the [[film director|director]]/[[photographer]] and the [[advertising agency]] or even the end client. A weekly broadcast television show may have significant deadline challenges for obvious reasons.
Often the decision makers are geographically dispersed, which may explain why commercial and print scouts have been early adopters of online presentations and other digital technologies.
== Additional duties == The Locations Department's duties often extend beyond pre-production and into actual production as well as after filming at the location has completed; a Location Manager and/or other Locations Department members are often needed during actual shooting and at wrap to be a general point of internal contact for matters related to the Locations Department such as ensuring smooth crew movement to and from the location, answering locations-related questions/ solving misc problems as may arise, coordinating crowd control and as an external point of contact between production and such parties as perhaps the property owner, neighbors, local [http://afci.org film office]/government and law enforcement.
Locations Department personnel are always the last crew to leave a location and the credo is to leave the location in the same (if not better) condition than it was found.
==Job titles and job descriptions== A film crew might have the following titled positions staffed in regard to the Locations Department. Many of the positions often "cross over" or a member of the department might "wear several hats":
;Location Manager Oversees the Locations Department and its staff, typically reporting directly to the Production Manager and/or Assistant Director (or even Director and/or Executive Producer). Location Manager is responsible for final clearing (or guaranteeing permission to use) a location for filming and must often assist Production/Finance Dept(s) in maintaining budget management regarding actual location/permit fees as well as labor costs to production for himself and the Locations Department at large.
;Assistant Location Manager Works with the Location Manager and the various departments in arranging technical scouts for the essential staff (grips, electric, camera, etc.) to see options which the Location Manager has selected for filming. The Assistant Location Manager will be onset during the filming process to oversee the operation, whereas the Location Manager continues preproduction from elsewhere (generally an office) on the upcoming locations. (Note: On most location-based television shows, there will be two Assistant Location Managers that alternate episodes, allowing one to prep an upcoming episode while the other is on set with the current one.)
;Location Scout Does much of the actual research, footwork and photography to document location possibilities. Often the Location Manager will do some scouting themselves, as well as the Assistant Location Manager.
;Location Researcher/Coordinator On a large film crew someone might be assigned exclusively to do research work for the Locations Department, freeing the Location Scout(s) to concentrate on photographing location possibilities or other tasks. This person's job might be to do internet or public library research and contact resources to assess said resource's interest in being involved in the film project and if such interest exists, the location researcher might be responsible for setting up an appointment for a location scout to go there.
;Location Assistant Hired by the Location Manager to be on-set before, during, and after the filming process. General responsibilities can include arriving first at the location to allow the set dressers into the set for preparation; maintaining the cleanliness of the location areas during filming (on larger budget projects this can include securing and supervising a contract clean-up crew or assigning such duties to a set PA); limiting the impact of a working production crew on the location grounds; fielding complaints from neighbors; and ultimately, at the end of the filming, managing on-set time and crew with regard to the closure of the location within contractually-permitted time constraints. There are generally one to three assistants on a shoot at any given time.
;Location Production Assistant This position exists generally on larger budget productions. The Locations PA is the assistant who is almost never onset, but instead is always "prepping" a location or "wrapping" a location. That is, when a location requires several days of set up and breakdown prior and following the day(s) of filming.
;Parking Coordinator Typically hired by Location Manager on an as-need basis to supervise Parking Staff in order to secure and coordinate crew parking including equipment trucks and personal vehicles. Locations Department and Parking Department might work together with local law enforcement to coordinate traffic control if the scene being filmed involves roadway right-of-way in any way.
;Parking Staff Parking Staff hang up the brightly colored signs that declare No Parking and then sit in their cars (with an orange cone on the top) to ensure that no one parks in the coned off areas.
;Waste Removal Location Department's disposition is to be the last to depart a location upon wrap and to leave the location in exactly if not better condition as it existed upon arrival. A waste removal company might be hired on an as-need basis.
==Methods== A location scout typically takes descriptive, [[panoramic photography|panoramic photographs]] or video of location possibilities. A good location scout will make photos of a location possibility that reflect the aesthetic goals of the production and will also include visually descriptive utilitarian photography and information in his presentation, documenting much more than just what will potentially appear onscreen.
Additional descriptive information might include (as might be relevant): *Reverse/alternate angle (photographing ''toward'' where camera might be), panoramic photography, to show space available for camera, lighting, video assist, hair and makeup (and clients on a commercial shoot) *Geographic coordinates, compass directions, other map data as may be applicable *Ambient lighting conditions at various times of day (or night), solar data, ''i.e.'', angle of sun at different times of day *Photos of holding/staging areas and available parking and/or parking restriction signage *Hand sketches of street/building layout(s), building/room floor plan(s), room or area dimension data *Crew/vehicle access data, ''i.e.'', doorways, hallways, elevators, stairs, availability and information of personnel needed for access *Notes regarding ambient sound conditions *On the shoot day, if a set is to be "dressed" ([[Theatrical property|props]]/furniture added or (re)moved), Locations Department and/or Art Department/[[Property master|Property Master]] Staff/Prop Stylist will photograph the specific areas to be affected so as to assure that the location will be returned to its original state once filming is completed.
== References == {{Reflist}}
== See also == *[[Location manager]], the person responsible for the locations department *[[Recce (filmmaking)|Recce]], reconnaissance visit to a shooting location *[[Teamsters]] International Brotherhood of Teamsters (IBT), the [[United States|American]] [[labor union]] representing commercial location scouts in California, New York and other filmmaking markets. The DGA (Directors Guild of America) represent Location Managers in Chicago and New York. *[[Location Managers Guild International]], a guild representing location scouts. *[[Filming location]], filming location *[[Filmmaking]], film production *[[Television advertisement]], television advertisement *[[Location library]], location library
== External links == * [http://www.locationmanagers.org/ Location Managers Guild International] (LMGI) * [http://alsam.net/ Association of Location Scouts and Managers (ALSAM)] * [http://www.golm.org.uk/ UK Guild of Location Managers] (GOLM) * [http://www.crossroadscouts.net/ Crossroads United Locations Department Workers (ULDW)]
{{film crew}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Location Scouting}} [[Category:Filmmaking occupations]] [[Category:Film location shooting]]

{{about|the media company that existed from 1994 to 2011|the successor company|AfreecaTV Co., Ltd.}} {{Infobox company | name = Nowcom | logo = | type = [[Public company|Public]] ({{kosdaq|026330}})
(until 2011)
[[Public company|Public]] ({{kosdaq|067160}})(present) | foundation = 1994 | defunct = 2011 | fate = Divided into [[AfreecaTV Co., Ltd.]] and ZettaMedia | location = [[Gyeonggi-do]], [[Republic of Korea]] | key_people = ex-CEO Yong-sik Moon {{cite press release |url= http://www.koreaherald.com/business/Detail.jsp?newsMLId=20101031000262 |publisher= The Korea Herald |title= Shinsegae, Nowcom heads face off on Twitter |date= 2010-10-31 |accessdate= 2011-01-14 }} | industry = [[Content Delivery Network]], [[Video game industry]], [[Media industry]] | products = [[Afreeca]], [[TalesRunner]], O2Jam, [[ClubBox]], [[Nownuri]] | revenue = | operating_income = | slogan = | net_income = | num_employees = 300 | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = {{URL|http://www.nowcom.co.kr|nowcom.co.kr}}(former)
{{URL|http://www.zettamedia.co.kr|zettamedia.co.kr}}(present)
{{URL|http://corp.afreecatv.com/|corp.afreecatv.com}}(present) | footnotes = }} '''Nowcom''' ({{kosdaq|026330}}) founded in 1994, was a Korean IT Company. Effective 2011, this corporate entity changed its name to '''AfreecaTV Co., Ltd''' ({{kosdaq|067160}}) after the AfreecaTV Co.,Ltd-ZettaMedia split. The first service of Nowcom in South Korea was ''Nownuri'' which is VT-based online BBS started in 1994 and currently they operate ''[[Afreeca]]'', ''[[TalesRunner]]'', ''O2Jam'' and ''[[ClubBox]]'' as well as ''Nownuri''. Nowcom was merged by '''[[Wins Technet]]''', a listed IT company, at January 2008 and listed on [[KOSDAQ]] with its original name though and worked together for 3 years, but finally they have been separated again to two companies as they were. Nowcom is still listed on KOSDAQ. On July 2011, Nowcom announced that its assets would be split into one publicly traded company and the other privately held company.http://www.zettamedia.co.kr/app/noticeView.php?b_no=5&pageNo=1 Another firm known as '''ZettaMedia''' was also established at that date and is a new spin-off company created during the split. == Services == * [[Afreeca]]: Online TV with P2P video streaming service. Users can upload their own videos as well as live video streams.{{cite web|url=http://joongangdaily.joins.com/article/view.asp?aid=2832563|title=Online broadcasters share their passion with viewers|accessdate=22 September 2009|date=24 October 2006|publisher=Joongang Daily|author=Limb Jae-un}} * [[TalesRunner]]: [[Racing video game]] * O2Jam: [[Music video game]] * [[ClubBox]]: Web storage service for any internet community * [[Nownuri]]: Classic VT BBS * [[NOWCDN]]: CDN service for massive file distribution such as game clients == Split == On July 2011, Nowcom announced that, after concerns from business differences between AfreecaTV and ClubBox, Nowcom's assets would be split into one publicly traded company, one oriented towards webcasting and online game development, and the other privately held company towards contents, media,and web storage. The split formally took place on July, 2011; where the present Nowcom was renamed AfreecaTV Co., Ltd. and consists primarily of ''[[Afreeca]]'', ''[[TalesRunner]]'', and ''O2Jam'', while a new ZettaMedia was formed to take on ''[[Nownuri]]'', PDBox, and ''[[ClubBox]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.ddaily.co.kr/news/news_view.php?uid=77943 |title=Nowcom Will Create "ZettaMedia" for Web Storage Business|publisher=Digital Daily|date=2011-05-13 |accessdate=2013-10-19}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20101231153000/http://nowcom.co.kr/ Nowcom Website] [[Category:Software companies of South Korea]] [[Category:Entertainment companies of South Korea]] [[Category:Video game companies of South Korea]] [[Category:Internet companies]] [[Category:Video game publishers]] [[Category:Video game development companies]] [[Category:Entertainment companies established in 1994]] [[Category:Video game companies established in 1994]] [[Category:1994 establishments in South Korea]] {{tech-company-stub}}

revision.comment: standard quote handling in WP;standard Apostrophe/quotation marks in WP;add/change/refine category; MOS fixes using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{more citations needed|date=June 2014}}
The term '''''online deliberation''''' describes the emerging field of practice and research related to the design, implementation and study of [[Deliberation|deliberative]] processes that rely on the use of electronic [[information and communications technologies]] (ICT).
Online deliberation is a relatively new field.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Davies |first1=Todd |last2=Chandler |first2=Reid |editor-last= |editor-first= |title=Democracy in Motion |publisher=Oxford University Press |date=2012 |pages=113 |chapter=Chapter 6: Online Deliberation Design |isbn=978-0-19-989928-9 |lastauthoramp=y |quote=Online deliberation is a relatively new field. Although the concept of public deliberation via electronic means was discussed as early as the 1970s,<sup>25</sup> and there was some early empirical work on deliberation online in the 1980s and 1990s,<sup>26</sup> studies of structured or public online deliberation appear to have begun with work by Stephen Coleman and colleagues,<sup>27</sup> Lincoln Dahlberg,<sup>28</sup> and Vincent Price<sup>29</sup> around a decade ago. }}</ref>
Online deliberation is very interdisciplinary, and includes practices such as [[online consultation]], [[e-participation]], [[E-government|e-governmen]]<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Yildiz|first=Mete|title=E-government research: Reviewing the literature, limitations, and ways forward|url=https://doi.org/10.1016/j.giq.2007.01.002|journal=Government Information Quarterly|volume=24|issue=3|pages=646–665|doi=10.1016/j.giq.2007.01.002}}</ref>[[E-government|t]],<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Halpern|first=Daniel|last2=Gibbs|first2=Jennifer|date=2013-05-01|title=Social media as a catalyst for online deliberation? Exploring the affordances of Facebook and YouTube for political expression|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0747563212002762|journal=Computers in Human Behavior|language=en|volume=29|issue=3|pages=1159–1168|doi=10.1016/j.chb.2012.10.008|issn=0747-5632|via=}}</ref> Citizen-to-Citizen (C2C),<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> online [[deliberative polling]], [[crowdsourcing]], [[online facilitation]], [[online research communities]], interactive [[e-learning]], civic dialogue in [[Internet forums]] and [[online chat]], and [[group decision making]] that utilizes [[collaborative decision-making software|collaborative software]] and other forms of [[computer-mediated communication]]. Work in all these endeavors is tied together by the challenge of using electronic media in a way that deepens thinking and improves mutual understanding.
Open international conferences on online deliberation have been held at [[Carnegie Mellon University]] in 2003, [[Stanford University]] in 2005, and the [[University of California, Berkeley]] in 2008. The most recent conference was held at the [[University of Leeds]], June 30 – July 2, 2010. Attendees of the 2005 conference voted to create an international society for online deliberation, but no formal organization has yet been established. Other events of interest have been sponsored by the Online Deliberative Democracy Consortium.<ref>[http://www.deliberative-democracy.net/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=84&Itemid=279 Online Deliberative Democracy Consortium]</ref>
== Definition == Over the past few decades, scholars across research traditions and areas have commonly identified at least two aspects in their definitions of [[deliberation]]: (1) a form of communication characterized by "the performance of a set of communicative behaviors that promote thorough group discussion";<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Burkhalter|first=Stephanie|last2=Gastil|first2=John|last3=Kelshaw|first3=Todd|date=2002-11-01|title=A Conceptual Definition and Theoretical Model of Public Deliberation in Small Face?to?Face Groups|url=https://academic.oup.com/ct/article/12/4/398-422/4110430|journal=Communication Theory|language=en|volume=12|issue=4|pages=398–422|doi=10.1111/j.1468-2885.2002.tb00276.x|issn=1050-3293}}</ref> and (2) the idea that individuals involved in this process of communication carefully weigh arguments and reasons for and against some propositions posed by others in the group.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gastil|first=John|date=2000|title=Is face-to-face citizen deliberation a luxury or a necessity?|url=|journal=Political Communication|volume=17|pages=357–361|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Schudson|first=Michael|date=1997|title=Why conversation is not the soul of democracy|url=https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/15295039709367020|journal=Critical Studies in Mass Communication|volume=14|pages=297–309|via=}}</ref> To be considered deliberative discussion, argue scholars, the communication and the involved interactants' behavior has to meet criteria established by the principles of political equality and egalitarian reciprocity.<ref name=":2" /><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/24067411|title=Democracy and deliberation : new directions for democratic reform|last=S.|first=Fishkin, James|date=1991|publisher=Yale University Press|isbn=9780300051636|location=New Haven|oclc=24067411}}</ref><ref name=":1" />
According to Habermas,<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/18327374|title=The structural transformation of the public sphere : an inquiry into a category of bourgeois society|last=Jürgen,|first=Habermas,|isbn=9780262081801|location=Cambridge, Mass.|oclc=18327374}}</ref> deliberation is "an interchange of rational–critical arguments among a group of individuals, triggered by a common or public problem, whose main focus or topic of discussion is to find a solution acceptable to all who have a stake in the issue".<ref name=":1" /> Halpern and Gibbs define deliberation as "a particular sort of discussion between at least two individuals in which (1) the form of communication emphasizes the use of logic and reasoning instead of power or coercion, (2) this reasoned engagement focuses on a social or political issue through which participants are able to identify solutions to a common problem, and (3) individuals are open to opinions and ideas expressed by others, and at the same time the communication between them is governed by rules of equality, symmetry and civility".<ref name=":1" /> Stroud and colleagues noted that many definitions of deliberation "share the basic idea that deliberation involves people exchanging views on a matter of public importance in a respectful manner, reasoning through their claims, and listening to the perspectives of others".<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Stroud|first=Natalie Jomini|last2=Scacco|first2=Joshua M.|last3=Muddiman|first3=Ashley|last4=Curry|first4=Alexander L.|date=2015-03-01|title=Changing Deliberative Norms on News Organizations' Facebook Sites|url=https://academic.oup.com/jcmc/article/20/2/188-203/4067559|journal=Journal of Computer-Mediated Communication|language=en|volume=20|issue=2|pages=188–203|doi=10.1111/jcc4.12104}}</ref>
The advent of the Internet and subsequently Web 2.0-based applications and especially [[social media]] have fostered discursive participation and deliberation online through [[computer-mediated communication]].<ref name=":1" />
== Implications for democracy ==
=== Advantages === Political deliberation is critical to societal consensus-building.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Scheufele|first=Dietram|last2=Nisbet|first2=Matthew|date=2002|title=Being a citizen online: New opportunities and dead ends|url=http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/abs/10.1177/1081180x0200700304|journal=The International Journal of Press/Politics|volume=7|pages=55–75|via=}}</ref> Online deliberation can have positive implications for the democracy. Research has found that social media can enhance civic participation and democratic decision-making.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Lerman|first=K.|date=November 2007|title=User Participation in Social Media: Digg Study|url=http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/4427583/|journal=2007 IEEE/WIC/ACM International Conferences on Web Intelligence and Intelligent Agent Technology - Workshops|pages=255–258|doi=10.1109/wi-iatw.2007.68|arxiv=0708.2414}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Macintosh|first=A.|date=January 2004|title=Characterizing e-participation in policy-making|url=http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/1265300/|journal=37th Annual Hawaii International Conference on System Sciences, 2004. Proceedings of the|pages=10 pp.–|doi=10.1109/hicss.2004.1265300}}</ref> First, online spaces allow for more equal and decentralized communication as numerous users from diverse backgrounds connect. Participants have equal opportunities to express opinions, raise questions, and exchange information.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Janssen|first=Davy|last2=Kies|first2=Raphaël|date=2005-09-01|title=Online Forums and Deliberative Democracy|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1057/palgrave.ap.5500115|journal=Acta Politica|language=en|volume=40|issue=3|pages=317–335|doi=10.1057/palgrave.ap.5500115|issn=0001-6810}}</ref> Secondly, online tools constitute a more favorable channel for users to engage in rational-critical debate than traditional synchronous channels because users are able to compose messages at their own pace and will.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Dahlberg|first=Lincoln|date=2001-10-01|title=Computer-Mediated Communication and The Public Sphere: A Critical Analysis|url=https://academic.oup.com/jcmc/article/4584246|journal=Journal of Computer-Mediated Communication|language=en|volume=7|issue=1|pages=0–0|doi=10.1111/j.1083-6101.2001.tb00137.x}}</ref> Thirdly, the written and asynchronous features of online deliberation enable more reflexive, rational and argumentative conversations.<ref name=":4">{{Cite book|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/9781444314861.ch8/summary|title=The Handbook of Internet Studies|last=Stromer-Galley|first=Jennifer|last2=Wichowski|first2=Alexis|date=2011|publisher=Wiley-Blackwell|isbn=9781444314861|editor-last=Consalvo|editor-first=Mia|pages=168–187|language=en|doi=10.1002/9781444314861.ch8|editor-last2=Ess|editor-first2=Charles}}</ref>
=== Disadvantages === Researchers have questioned the utility of online deliberation as an extension of the [[public sphere]], declining the idea that online deliberation is no less beneficial than face-to-face interaction.<ref name=":1" /> Computer-mediated discourse is deemed impersonal, and is found to encourage [[online incivility]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kiesler|first=Sara|last2=Siegel|first2=Jane|last3=McGuire|first3=Timothy W.|title=Social psychological aspects of computer-mediated communication.|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1037/0003-066X.39.10.1123|journal=American Psychologist|language=en|volume=39|issue=10|pages=1123–1134|doi=10.1037/0003-066x.39.10.1123}}</ref> Furthermore, users who participate in online discussions about politics are found to make comments only in groups that agree with their own views,<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/38879177|title=The web of politics : the internet's impact on the American political system|last=1955-|first=Davis, Richard,|date=1999|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=0195114841|location=New York|oclc=38879177}}</ref> indicating the possibility that online deliberation mainly promotes [[motivated reasoning]] and reinforces preexisting attitudes.
== Quality of Online Deliberation ==
=== Deliberative Norms === In the context of new media environment, researchers have evaluated the quality of online discourse based on criteria such as the presence of civility,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Papacharissi|first=Zizi|date=2004|title=Democracy online: Civility, politeness, and the democratic potential of online political discussion groups|url=|journal=New Media & Society|volume=6|pages=259–283|via=}}</ref> relevance,<ref name=":4" /> genuine questions, and evidence to determine if the discourse meets the deliberative norms.<ref name=":3" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ruiz|first=Carlos|last2=Domingo|first2=David|last3=Lluís Micó|first3=Josep|last4=Díaz-Noci|first4=Javier|last5=Meso|first5=Koldo|last6=Masip|first6=Pere|date=2011|title=Public Sphere 2.0? The Democratic Qualities of Citizen Debates in Online Newspapers|url=|journal=The International Journal of Press/Politics|volume=16|pages=463–487|via=}}</ref>
=== Factors Influencing online deliberation === In the context of comments posted to online news sites, the presence of a recognizable journalist engaging with commenters has been found to be associated with improved quality of deliberation with reduced incivility and increased evidence-based discourse, as compared with when no one engages with commenters or when an unidentified staff member from the news organization engages with commenters.<ref name=":3" /> Discussions surrounding news of health or abortion topics are more relevant but with fewer genuine questions posed than news of topics on education, crimes or guns, and economy. News of education topics has less uncivil and more relevant comments than the other news topics. People provide less evidence in their discourse when discussing news of economy topics as compared to the other news topics.<ref name=":3" />
Group size, volume of communication, interactivity between participants, message characteristics, and social media characteristics have also been found to impact online deliberation.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Eveland|first=William P|last2=Hively|first2=Myiah Hutchens|date=2009-06-01|title=Political Discussion Frequency, Network Size, and "Heterogeneity" of Discussion as Predictors of Political Knowledge and Participation|url=https://academic.oup.com/joc/article/59/2/205-224/4098354|journal=Journal of Communication|language=en|volume=59|issue=2|pages=205–224|doi=10.1111/j.1460-2466.2009.01412.x|issn=0021-9916}}</ref><ref name=":1" />
== Online Political Deliberation == Deliberation can be defined as being the "act of thinking about or discussing something and deciding carefully" by the Merriam-Webster dictionary. In an online political setting, however, it is more complicated than only reaching a decision. Members need to contribute material with an intent for it to be discussed and responded to by others. Participants of online deliberation need to diligently analyze, review, and present the sources of their findings before any decisions can be made. A consensus has to be reached among members of which material to use based on relevancy and quality, and ability to accurately resolve the issue of which they are trying to find a solution to.
Generally, participation in online deliberation forums has been low. This is an issue because representativity is poor and can be swayed towards meeting the wishes of those that participate, consisting of those who are well-educated, and so forth. There is also the possibility that the issues wouldn't even be considered if turnout remains so low. Low levels of influence not only repel legislative bodies, but also potential participants. However, large participation levels present the chance that members are beginning to solely chat on topics, not fully read and evaluate others' inputs. If a forum is deliberate and goal-oriented, and those who participate are forced to have to go through processes to get their opinions out, those who wish to simply chatter will be filtered out, and the forums will be left only with those seriously interested and involved in finding a solution, as explored by Cyril Velikanov in his "Mass Online Deliberation" paper.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Velikanov|first=Cyril|title=Mass Online Deliberation|url=https://www.academia.edu/12031548/Mass_Online_Deliberation|language=en}}</ref>
=== Participatory Factors === Online deliberation Internet forums require participants to be able to work together comfortably in order to make the best possible deliberations. In order to do that, as Beth Noveck has put it, forums need to establish "physics" for groups, or rules and regulations have to follow in order for members to feel comfortable with one another.<ref name=":02">{{Cite book|title=Wiki Government: How Technology Can Make Government Better, Democracy Stronger, and Citizens More Powerful|last=Noveck|first=Beth|publisher=Brookings Institution Press|year=2009}}</ref> Once comfort is achieved, the environment groups are now in are their "culture," and healthy conversations can now be made. Since participants do not communicate face-to-face, visual queues often make groups more self-aware. For instance, green and red lights can be implemented for when members speak, and therefore the group can visualize if a member isn't participating or involved, or if a member is ''too'' involved. This way, imbalances in groups can be avoided, such as gridlocked situations or communication flaws.
=== Work Management === Systems of "chunking work," or, members self-selecting roles to play in their groups, help to keep work high quality and manageable.<ref name=":02" /> Collaboration becomes easier when people choose the way they want to work in whatever way suits them. When members select the method of working that is comfortable to them, they are more likely to remain interested in their subject and produce quality content for their group. If Internet forums can find a way to divide work in a way that members are most comfortable, their outcomes will be better produced.
=== Rating Systems === Rating systems are valuable to Internet forums because they police both participants and the content they produce to ensure quality material. If members can rate each other based on their collaboration or work produced, then they can more easily trust those who have high ratings to have quality product. The forums themselves can also see these ratings and be able to filter out inappropriate, irrelevant, or low-quality content. Members policing each other forces the members to be cautious and aware about the information they put out. Ratings help to regulate and organize the sites on a large scale, making it easier to sift through content even if there are large amounts of it.
== See also == {{div col|colwidth=22em}} * [[Argument map]] (section [[Argument map#Online.2C collaborative|Online, collaborative]]) * [[Collaborative software]] * [[Computer-mediated communication]] * [[Computer supported cooperative work]] * [[Deliberation]] * [[Deliberative democracy]] * [[Deliberative opinion poll]] * [[E-democracy]] * [[E-participation]] * [[Online consultation]] * [[Online participation]] * [[Online research communities]] * [[Public sphere]] * [[Social media]] * [[Web annotation]] * Popular tools: ** [[DemocracyOS]] ** [[LiquidFeedback]] {{div col end}}
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * [http://online-deliberation.net Online deliberation resources] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060314061609/http://caae.phil.cmu.edu/style/Seminar.html Developing and Using Online Tools for Deliberative Democracy] - the first conference on online deliberation, Carnegie Mellon University (June 2003) * [http://www.online-deliberation.net/conf2005/ Online Deliberation 2005 / DIAC-2005] - the Second Conference on Online Deliberation: Design, Research, and Practice, Stanford University (May 2005) * [http://www.publicsphereproject.org/events/diac08/ Tools for Participation: Collaboration, Deliberation, and Decision Support (DIAC-2008/OD2008)] - the Third Conference on Online Deliberation, University of California, Berkeley (June 2008) * [http://www.od2010.dico.unimi.it/ The Fourth International Conference on Online Deliberation] - University of Leeds (June 30-July 2, 2010) "Online Deliberation: A Review of The Literature." Bang The Table, 7 Aug. 2017, www.bangthetable.com/online-deliberation/. "Online Deliberation." Online Deliberation | Participedia, participedia.net/en/methods/online-deliberation. Esau, Katharina, et al. "Design Matters! An Empirical Analysis of Online Deliberation on Different News Platforms." Policy & Internet, Wiley-Blackwell, 4 Aug. 2017, onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1002/poi3.154.

(PT Mega Media Indonesia) | groups = | launch_date = 2012 | affiliates = | website = [http://www.orangetv.co.id/ www.orangetv.co.id] }} '''OrangeTV''' is a subscription-based direct broadcast satellite (DBS) or direct-to-home satellite television operated by PT Mega Media Indonesia, subsidiary of the MEI. Orange TV has operated nationwide in Indonesia since 2012. Starting 2013 season, OrangeTV had the opportunity to be the official broadcast [[Premier League]] through a partnership with MP & Silva. == List of channels == === Premium channels === Until May 11, 2018 * [[Festival (TV channels)|Festival Channel]] * [[Dangdut Channel]] * [[Top Hits]] * [[Celestial Movies]] * [[Diva Universal]] * [[Kix (Asian TV channel)|KIX]] * [[Thrill (TV channel)|Thrill]] * [[KBS World]] * [[HBO (Asia)|HBO]] * [[HBO Family]] * [[HBO Signature]] * [[HBO Hits]] * [[Fight Sports]] * [[beIN Sports|beIN Sports 1]] * [[beIN Sports|beIN Sports 2]] * [[beIN Sports|beIN Sports 3 Premier League]] === Free channels === *[[SCTV (Indonesia)|SCTV]] *[[Antv|ANTV]] *[[tvOne (Indonesia)|tvOne]] *[[MetroTV]] *[[Televisi Republik Indonesia|TVRI]] *[[Indosiar]] *[[Trans TV]] *[[Trans7]] *[[Kompas TV]] *[[NET.]] *[[MNC TV]] *[[CNN Indonesia]] *[[GTV (Indonesia)|GTV]] *[[Rajawali Televisi|RTV]] *[[INTV (Indonesia)]] *[[iNews]] *[[Gramedia TV]] *[[RCTI]] == External links == * [http://www.orangetv.co.id Official website] * [http://www.lyngsat.com/packages/Orange-TV-Ku.html Channel and transponder list] {{TV Providers in Indonesia}} {{CATV Africa, Asia, and Oceania}} [[Category:Direct broadcast satellite services]] [[Category:Television in Indonesia]]

'''Pentameter''' (from [[Ancient Greek|Greek]]: {{lang|grc| πεντάμετρος}} - 'measuring five ([[Foot (prosody)|feet]])') is a [[poet]]ic [[meter (poetry)|meter]]. А [[poem]] is said to be written in a particular pentameter when the [[line (poetry)|lines]] of the poem have the length of '''five feet''', where 'foot' is a combination of a particular number (1 or 2) of unstressed (or weak) [[syllable]]s and a stressed (or strong) syllable. Depending on the pattern of feet, pentameter can be iambic (one of three two-syllable meters alongside [[Trochee|trochaic]] and [[Spondee|spondaic]]) or dactylic (one of two three-syllable meters alongside [[Anapaest|anapestic]]) (see links below).
This class of meters includes: *[[Dactylic pentameter]] of [[Ancient history|antiquity]] *[[Iambic pentameter]] of [[modernity]]
[[Category:Poetry]]

revision.text:
{{Redirect|Periodical||Periodicity (disambiguation){{!}}Periodicity}} [[File:PLoS Biology cover April 2009.svg|thumb|The cover of an issue of the [[open-access journal]] ''[[PLOS Biology]]'', published monthly by the [[Public Library of Science]]]] '''Periodical literature''' (also called a '''periodical publication''' or simply a '''periodical''') is a category of [[Serial (literature)|serial]] [[published|publication]]<nowiki/>s that appear in a new edition on a regular schedule.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc-clio.com/ODLIS/odlis_P.aspx?#periodical |title=Periodical |work=ODLIS — Online Dictionary for Library and Information Science |publisher=ABC-Clio |date= |accessdate=2012-08-06}}</ref> The most familiar example is the [[magazine]], typically published weekly, monthly, or quarterly. [[Newspaper]]s, often published daily or weekly, are, strictly speaking, a separate category of [[Serial (publishing)|serial]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc-clio.com/ODLIS/odlis_N.aspx?#newspaper |title=Newspaper |work=ODLIS — Online Dictionary for Library and Information Science |publisher=ABC-Clio |date= |accessdate=2015-07-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc-clio.com/ODLIS/odlis_S.aspx?#serial |title=Serial |work=ODLIS — Online Dictionary for Library and Information Science |publisher=ABC-Clio |date=2006-11-12 |accessdate=2012-08-06}}</ref> Other examples of periodicals are [[newsletter]]s, [[literary magazine]]s (literary journals), [[academic journal]]s (including [[scientific journal]]s), [[List of science magazines|science magazine]]s, [[yearbook]]s and [[comic book]]s.
==Volumes and issues== These examples are typically published and referenced by [[Volume (bibliography)|volume]] and issue. ''Volume'' typically refers to the number of years the publication has been circulated, and ''issue'' refers to how many times that periodical has been published during that year. For example, the April 2011 publication of a monthly magazine first published in 2002 would be listed as, "volume 10, issue 4". [[Roman numerals]] are sometimes used in reference to the volume number.
When [[Citation|citing]] a work in a periodical, there are standardized formats such as ''[[The Chicago Manual of Style]]''. In the latest edition of this style, a work with volume number 17 and issue number 3 may be written as follows:
* James M. Heilman, and Andrew G. West. "Wikipedia and Medicine: Quantifying Readership, Editors, and the Significance of Natural Language." ''Journal of Medical Internet Research'' 17, no. 3 (2015). doi:10.2196/jmir.4069.
==Popular and scholarly== [[File:Cover of Science in School 32.jpg|thumb|upright|Cover of ''Science in School'' magazine<ref>{{cite web|title=Cover of Science in School 32|url=http://www.eso.org/public/images/ann15057a/|accessdate=13 July 2015}}</ref>]]
Periodicals can be classified into two types: popular and scholarly. Popular periodicals are usually magazines (e.g., ''[[Ebony (magazine)|Ebony]]'' and ''[[Esquire (magazine)|Esquire]]''). [[academic journal|Scholarly journal]]s are most commonly found in libraries and databases. Examples are ''[[The Journal of Psychology]]'' and the ''[[Journal of Social Work]]''.
[[Trade magazine]]s are also examples of periodicals. They are written for an audience of professionals in the world. As of the early 1990s, there were over 6,000 business, technical, academic, scientific, and trade publications in the United States alone.<ref>{{cite book |first=Gary |last= Blake |author1-link= Gary Blake |first2= Robert W. |last2= Bly |author2-link= Robert W. Bly |last-author-amp= yes |title= The Elements of Technical Writing |page= 113. |location= New York |publisher= [[Macmillan Publishers (United States)|Macmillan Publishers]] |year= 1993 |isbn= 0020130856}}</ref>
==Indefinite vs. part-publication== These examples are related to the idea of an indefinitely continuing cycle of production and publication: magazines plan to continue publishing, not to stop after a predetermined number of editions. A novel, in contrast, might be published in monthly parts, a method revived after the success of ''[[The Pickwick Papers]]'' by [[Charles Dickens]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.bl.uk/collections/early/victorian/pu_novel.html |work= Aspects of the Victorian Book |title= The Novel |via= The British Library}}</ref> This approach is called '''part-publication''', particularly when each part is from a whole work, or a [[Serial (literature)|serial]], for example in [[comic book]]s. It flourished during the nineteenth century, for example with [[Abraham John Valpy]]'s ''Delphin Classics'', and was not restricted to [[fiction]].<ref>{{cite book |first1= Simon |last1= Eliot |first2= Jonathan |last2= Rose |last-author-amp=yes |title= A Companion to the History of the Book |year= 2007 |page= 297}}{{full citation needed|date= February 2015}}</ref>
==Standard numbers== The [[International Standard Serial Number]] (ISSN) is to serial publications (and by extension, periodicals) what the [[International Standard Book Number]] (ISBN) is to books: a standardized reference number.
==Distribution== Postal services often carry periodicals at a preferential rate; for example, Second Class Mail in the United States only applies to publications issued at least quarterly.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.answers.com/topic/second-class-mail |title= Second Class Mail |work= Barron's Business Dictionary |via= Answers.com}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Partwork]]
==References== {{EB1911 Poster|Periodicals}} {{reflist}}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Periodical Literature}} [[Category:Periodicals| ]] [[Category:Comics terminology]] [[Category:Publishing]]

revision.text:
{{for|National Pie Day|American Pie Council#National Pie Day}} {{Use mdy dates|date=July 2018}} {{Infobox holiday |holiday_name = Pi Day |image = prince-of-pi.jpg |caption = [[Larry Shaw (Pi)|Larry Shaw]], the organizer of the first Pi Day celebration at the [[Exploratorium]] in [[San Francisco]]. |observedby = |significance = 3, 1, and 4 are the three most [[significant figure]]s of {{pi}} in its decimal representation. |duration = 1 day |frequency = Annual |scheduling = same day each year |date = March 14 |mdy=y |firsttime=1988 |celebrations = [[Pie]] eating, discussions about {{pi}}<ref name="landau">{{Cite web |url=http://www.cnn.com/2010/TECH/03/12/pi.day.math/index.html |title=On Pi Day, one number 'reeks of mystery' |last=Landau |first=Elizabeth |date=March 12, 2010 |publisher=CNN |language=en |access-date=March 14, 2018}}</ref> |relatedto = Pi Approximation Day }} {{Pi box}}
'''Pi Day''' is an annual celebration of the mathematical constant [[pi|{{pi}} (pi)]]. Pi Day is observed on [[March 14]] (3/14 in the ''month/day'' [[date format|format]]) since 3, 1, and 4 are the first three [[Significant figures|significant digits]] of {{pi}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/science/2015/mar/13/pi-day-celebration-maths-fans-language-memory-contests|title=Pi Day 2015: a sweet treat for maths fans|last=Bellos|first=Alex|website=theguardian.com|date=March 14, 2015|accessdate=March 14, 2016}}</ref><ref>[http://sverigesradio.se/sida/avsnitt/514543?programid=412 Program on Sveriges Radio – Swedish national radio company] Read March 14, 2015</ref> In 2009, the [[United States House of Representatives]] supported the designation of Pi Day.<ref name=HORRes>United States. Cong. House. Supporting the designation of Pi Day, and for other purposes. 111th Cong. [http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/z?c111:H.RES.224: Library of Congress].</ref>
'''Pi Approximation Day''' is observed on [[July 22]] (22/7 in the ''day/month'' format), since the [[Fraction (mathematics)|fraction]] {{frac|22|7}} is a common [[Approximations of π|approximation of {{pi}}]], which is accurate to two decimal places and dates from [[Archimedes]].<ref name=VerizonTodayInHistory>{{cite web|title=Pi Approximation Day is celebrated today.|url=http://www.thinkfinity.org/2010-07-22_pi-approximation-day|work=Today In History|publisher=Verizon Foundation|accessdate=January 30, 2011}}</ref>
'''Two Pi Day''', also known as '''Tau Day''', is lightly observed on [[June 28]] (6/28 in the ''month/day'' format).<ref name="lightyears">[http://lightyears.blogs.cnn.com/2012/06/28/tau-day-why-you-should-eat-twice-the-pie/ Tau Day: Why you should eat twice the pie – Light Years – CNN.com Blogs] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130112211136/http://lightyears.blogs.cnn.com/2012/06/28/tau-day-why-you-should-eat-twice-the-pie/ |date=January 12, 2013 }}</ref>
== History == In 1988, the earliest known official or large-scale celebration of Pi Day was organized by [[Larry Shaw (Pi)|Larry Shaw]] at the [[Exploratorium|San Francisco Exploratorium]],<ref>{{cite web | url = http://articles.sfgate.com/2009-03-11/entertainment/17211858_1_pi-day-pi-shrine-einstein-s-birthday | title = Any way you slice it, pi's transcendental | last = Berton | first = Justin | date = March 11, 2009 | work = [[San Francisco Chronicle]] | accessdate=March 18, 2011 }}</ref> where Shaw worked as a [[physicist]],<ref name="ABC – Science – 10 Mar 2011 – infinite appeal of pi">{{Cite web |url=http://www.abc.net.au/science/articles/2011/03/10/3158045.htm?site=science/opinion |title=The infinite appeal of pi |last=Borwein |first=Jonathan |authorlink=Jonathan Borwein |date=March 10, 2011 |publisher=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] |access-date=March 13, 2011}}</ref> with staff and public marching around one of its circular spaces, then consuming fruit pies.<ref name="fresnobee">{{Cite news |url=http://apollotutoring.com/pi_day.pdf |title=A place where learning pi is a piece of cake |last=Apollo |first=Adrian |date=March 10, 2007 |publisher=[[The Fresno Bee]]}}</ref> The Exploratorium continues to hold Pi Day celebrations.<ref name=exploratorium>{{cite web|title=Exploratorium 22nd Annual Pi Day|url=http://www.exploratorium.edu/pi/index.html|publisher=Exploratorium|accessdate=January 31, 2011}}</ref>
On March 12, 2009, the U.S. House of Representatives passed a [[non-binding resolution]] ([[wikisource:H. RES. 224 Supporting the designation of Pi Day, and for other purposes|111 H. Res. 224]]),<ref name=HORRes /> recognizing March 14, 2009 as National Pi Day.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://news.cnet.com/8301-13578_3-10194354-38.html?part=rss&subj=news&tag=2547-1_3-0-5 | title = National Pi Day? Congress makes it official | work = Politics and Law | last = McCullagh | first = Declan | publisher = [[CNET News]] | date = March 11, 2009 | accessdate = March 14, 2009 }}</ref> For Pi Day 2010, Google presented a [[Google Doodle]] celebrating the holiday, with the word Google laid over images of circles and pi symbols;<ref name=GoogleDoodle>{{cite web|title=Pi Day|url=https://www.google.com/doodles/pi-day|work=Google Doodles|publisher=Google|accessdate=October 9, 2012}}</ref> and for the 30th anniversary in 2018, it was a [[Dominique Ansel]] pie with the [[circumference]] divided by its [[diameter]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.google.com/doodles/30th-anniversary-of-pi-day|title=30th Anniversary of Pi Day!|website=www.google.com|language=en|access-date=March 19, 2018}}</ref>
The entire month of March 2014 (3/14) was observed by some as "Pi Month".<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.popsci.com/article/science/its-not-just-pi-day-its-pi-month |title=It's Not Just Pi Day, It's Pi Month! |last=Main |first=Douglas |date=March 14, 2014 |publisher=Popular Science |access-date=July 22, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://cmns.umd.edu/news-events/events/1774 |title=Pi Month Celebration & Circle of Discovery Award Presentation | College of Computer, Mathematical, and Natural Sciences |publisher=Cmns.umd.edu |date=March 11, 2014 |accessdate=July 22, 2014}}</ref> In the year 2015, March 14 was celebrated as "Super Pi Day".<ref>https://www.forbes.com/sites/ericmack/2015/03/14/happy-super-pi-day-heres-how-to-celebrate/</ref> It had special significance, as the date is written as 3/14/15 in month/day/year format. At 9:26:53, the date and time together represented the first 10 digits of {{pi}}.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/pi-day-2015-2014-3 |title=March 14, 2015 Will Be A Once-In-A-Century Thrill For Math Geeks |last=Ro |first=Sam |date=March 13, 2014 |website=Business Insider |access-date=March 13, 2014}}</ref>
== Observance == Pi Day has been observed in many ways, including eating [[pie]], [[pieing|throwing pies]] and discussing the significance of the number {{pi}}, due to a [[pun]] based on the words "pi" and "pie" being homophones in English ({{IPAc-en|pron|p|aɪ}}), and the coincidental circular nature of a pie.<ref name=landau /><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/kionasmith/2018/03/14/wednesdays-google-doodle-celebrates-pi-day/|title=Wednesday's Google Doodle Celebrates Pi Day|first=K.N.|last=Smith|publisher=}}</ref>
[[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] has often mailed its [[College admissions in the United States#Application process|application decision letters]] to prospective students for delivery on Pi Day.<ref>{{Cite news | url = http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/17605924/ | title = Pi fans meet March 14 (3.14, get it?) | first = Erin | last = McClan | publisher = [[msnbc.com]] | date = March 14, 2007 | accessdate = January 24, 2008}}</ref> Starting in 2012, MIT has announced it will post those decisions (privately) online on Pi Day at exactly 6:28 pm, which they have called "Tau Time", to honor the rival numbers pi and [[Tau (2π)|tau]] equally.<ref>{{cite web|title=I have SMASHING news!|url=http://mitadmissions.org/blogs/entry/i-have-smashing-news|publisher=MIT Admissions|accessdate=March 12, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=McGann|first=Matt|title=Pi Day, Tau Time|url=http://mitadmissions.org/blogs/entry/pi-day-tau-time|publisher=MIT Admissions|accessdate=March 18, 2012}}</ref> In 2015, the regular decisions were put online at 9:26 AM, following that year's "pi minute".<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://mitadmissions.org/blogs/entry/keep-your-eyes-to-the-skies |title=Keep your eyes to the skies this Pi Day |publisher=MIT Admissions |language=en |access-date=March 14, 2018}}</ref> June 28 is "Two Pi Day", also known as "Tau Day". 2{{pi}}, also known by the Greek letter [[tau]] (τ) is a common multiple in mathematical formulae. Some have argued that τ is the more fundamental constant, and that Tau Day should be celebrated instead.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/science/pi-day-march-14-maths-google-doodle-pie-baking-celebrate-30-anniversary-a8254036.html|title=It's Pi Day today. But these people say we should refuse to celebrate it|date=March 13, 2018|work=The Independent|access-date=March 14, 2018|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2013/03/031314-pi-day-exploratorium-mathematics-pie-science/|title=Pi Day Turns 25: Why We Celebrate an Irrational Number|date=March 14, 2013|access-date=March 14, 2018}}</ref> Celebrations of this date jokingly suggest eating "twice the pie".<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Bartholomew|first1=Randyn Charles|title=Why Tau Trumps Pi|journal=Scientific American|url=https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/let-s-use-tau-it-s-easier-than-pi/|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Landau|first1=Elizabeth|title=In case Pi Day wasn't enough, it's now 'Tau Day' on the Internet|url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/TECH/innovation/06/28/tau.day.math/index.html|work=CNN|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Tau Day – Come Eat Twice the (Pi)e|url=https://www.geocaching.com/geocache/GC56WHN_tau-day-come-eat-twice-the-pie?guid=19c50aa3-fe1c-4961-8df8-f03f3798de91|language=en}}</ref>
[[Princeton, New Jersey]], hosts numerous events in a combined celebration of Pi Day and [[Albert Einstein]]'s birthday, which is also March 14.<ref name="princeton">{{Cite web |url=http://www.visitprinceton.org/activities/events/piday/ |title=Princeton Pi Day & Einstein Birthday Party |website=Princeton Regional Convention and Visitors Bureau |access-date=March 14, 2013}}</ref> Einstein lived in Princeton for more than twenty years while working at the [[Institute for Advanced Study]]. In addition to pie eating and recitation contests, there is an annual Einstein look-alike contest.<ref name="princeton" />
<gallery> File:Pi pie2.jpg|Pi Pie at [[Delft University]] File:Blackberry Pi.jpg|Blackberry Pi Pie File:Pi day sale.jpg|A grocery store selling pies for 3.14 dollars, Pi Day 2015 </gallery>
== See also == *[[Mole Day]] *[[Sequential time]] *[[Square Root Day]]
== References == {{Reflist|30em}}
== External links == {{Commons category|Pi Day}} *[http://www.exploratorium.edu/pi/ Exploratorium's Pi Day Web Site] *[https://www.npr.org/blogs/thetwo-way/2010/03/pi_day.html NPR provides a "Pi Rap" audiovideo] *[http://www.piday.org/ Pi Day] *[http://www.math.utep.edu/Faculty/lesser/piday.html Professor Lesser's Pi Day page]

{{Use mdy dates|date=December 2012}} {{Infobox website | name = Roller Coaster DataBase | logo = RCDB logo.gif | screenshot = Rcdb1.png | screenshot_size = 250px | caption = Roller Coaster DataBase logo and home page | url = [https://www.rcdb.com/ rcdb.com] | alexa = {{decreasePositive}} 172,496 ({{as of|2015|7|27|alt=July 2015}})<ref name="alexa">{{cite web|url= http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/rcdb.com |title= Rcdb.com Site Info | publisher= [[Alexa Internet]] |accessdate=July 27, 2015}}</ref> | commercial = | type = Database | language = 10 languages | registration = No | owner = Duane Marden | author = | launch date = 1996 | current status = Operating | revenue = | slogan = }} '''Roller Coaster DataBase''' ('''RCDB''') is a [[roller coaster]] and [[amusement park]] [[database]] begun in 1996 by Duane Marden.<ref name="owner">{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/travel/destinations/2006-06-17-fast-coasters_x.htm|title=Faster coasters have reliability issues|date=June 19, 2006|newspaper=[[USA Today]]|accessdate=April 8, 2010}}</ref> It has grown to feature statistics and photos of over 5000 roller coasters from around the world.<ref name="NYT Obsessions With Minutiae Thrive as Databases" />
Publications that have mentioned RCDB include ''[[The New York Times]]'',<ref name="NYT Obsessions With Minutiae Thrive as Databases">{{cite news|last=Cohen|first=Noam|title=Obsessions With Minutiae Thrive as Databases|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/04/business/media/04link.html?pagewanted=2 |accessdate=December 1, 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|date=October 3, 2010}}</ref> ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'',<ref name="LAT Looping wooden roller coasters are about to become a reality">{{cite news|last=MacDonald|first=Brady|title=Looping wooden roller coasters are about to become a reality|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2012/oct/25/news/la-trb-rocky-mountain-coasters-10201225|accessdate=December 1, 2012|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=October 25, 2012}}</ref> ''[[Toledo Blade]]'',<ref name="TB N.J. coaster gets raves, when it's working">{{cite news|title=N.J. coaster gets raves, when it's working|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=wckwAAAAIBAJ&sjid=dAQEAAAAIBAJ&dq=roller-coaster-database&pg=6851%2C631229|accessdate=December 1, 2012|newspaper=Toledo Blade|date=June 18, 2006}}</ref> ''[[Orlando Sentinel]]'',<ref name="OS A New Life For Old Coaster">{{cite news|title=A New Life For Old Coaster|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2007-07-14/news/STARLINER14_1_wooden-coaster-cypress-gardens-american-coaster-enthusiasts|accessdate=December 1, 2012|newspaper=Orlando Sentinel|date=July 14, 2007|author=Bevil, Dewayne|author2=Caviness, Tod}}</ref> ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'',<ref name="TIME In The Loop">{{cite journal|last=Shum|first=Keane|title=In The Loop|journal=Time |date=September 19, 2005|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1106455,00.html}}</ref> ''[[Forbes]]'',<ref name="Forbes The Most Blood-Curdling Coasters">{{cite journal|last=LaMotta|first=Lisa|title=The Most Blood-Curdling Coasters|journal=Forbes|date=October 25, 2007|url=https://www.forbes.com/2007/10/25/six-flags-rollercoaster-ent-manage-cx_ll_1025scaryrollercoaster.html}}</ref> ''[[Mail & Guardian]]'',<ref name="US's temperamental roller coasters" /> and ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]''.<ref name="CST New coaster coming to Gurnee Six Flags in 2012">{{cite news|last=Moran|first=Dan|title=New coaster coming to Gurnee Six Flags in 2012|url=http://newssun.suntimes.com/news/7407158-418/new-coaster-coming-to-gurnee-six-flags-in-2012.html|accessdate=December 1, 2012|newspaper=Chicago Sun-Times|date=September 1, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120323001059/http://newssun.suntimes.com/news/7407158-418/new-coaster-coming-to-gurnee-six-flags-in-2012.html|archivedate=March 23, 2012|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
==History== RCDB was started in 1996 by Duane Marden,<ref name="owner"/> a computer programmer from [[Brookfield, Wisconsin]].<ref name="US's temperamental roller coasters">{{cite news|title=US's temperamental roller coasters|url=http://www.mg.co.za/article/2006-06-17-uss-temperamental-roller-coasters|accessdate=December 1, 2012|newspaper=Mail & Guardian|date=June 17, 2006}}</ref> The website is run off [[web server]]s in Marden's basement and a location in [[St. Louis]].<ref name="NYT Obsessions With Minutiae Thrive as Databases" /> As of 2015, Marden still operates the site.<ref name=About>{{cite RCDB|coaster_name=About This Site|accessdate=July 19, 2015|url=http://rcdb.com/about.htm}}</ref>
==Content== {{See also|List of defunct amusement parks}} Each roller coaster entry includes any of the following information for the ride: current amusement park location, type, status (existing, standing but not operating (SBNO), defunct), opening date, make/model, cost, capacity, length, height, drop, number of [[Roller coaster inversion|inversions]], speed, duration, maximum vertical angle, [[Train (roller coaster)|trains]], and special notes.<ref name="Reference Reviews">{{cite journal|last=Frederiksen|first=Linda|title=Roller Coaster Database|journal=Reference Reviews|year=2007|volume=21|issue=1|pages=51–55|issn=0950-4125}}</ref> Entries may also feature reader-contributed photos and/or [[press release]]s.<ref name="NYT Obsessions With Minutiae Thrive as Databases" />
The site also categorizes the rides into special orders, including a list of the tallest coasters, a list of the fastest coaster, a list of the most inversions on a coaster, a list of the parks with the most inversions, etc., each sortable by steel, wooden, or both. Each roller coaster entry links back to a page which lists all of that park's roller coasters, past and present, and includes a brief history and any links to fan web pages saluting the park.<ref name="Reference Reviews" />
==Languages== The site is available in ten languages: [[English language|English]], [[German language|German]], [[French language|French]], [[Spanish language|Spanish]], [[Dutch language|Dutch]], [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]], [[Italian language|Italian]], [[Swedish language|Swedish]], [[Japanese language|Japanese]] and [[Simplified Chinese]].<ref name=About /><ref name="Reference Reviews" />
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.rcdb.com/}}
[[Category:Online databases]] [[Category:Roller coasters]] [[Category:Entertainment databases]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2011}} {{Infobox music genre |name=Skweee |bgcolor=silver |color=black |stylistic_origins= {{hlist|[[Chiptune]]|[[minimal techno]]|[[Electro music|electro]]|[[funk]]|[[contemporary R&B]]|[[Soul music|soul]]|[[Middle Eastern music|Middle Eastern rhythms]]}} |cultural_origins=Late 2000s (decade), [[Sweden]] and [[Finland]] |instruments=[[Synthesizer]] |popularity=Underground }} [[Image:Skweee-records.jpg|right|250px|thumb|7" Skweee singles on sale at the [[Norbergfestival|Norberg Festival 2009]] in Sweden]] '''Skweee''' is a musical style, with origin in [[Sweden]] and [[Finland]]. Skweee combines simple [[synthpop|synth]]/[[chiptune]] leads and basslines with [[funk]], [[R&B]] or [[Soul music|soul]]-like rhythms, overall rendering a stripped-down funky sound. The tracks are predominantly instrumental, though there are exceptions. The name Skweee was coined by [[Daniel Savio]], one of the originators of the emerging sound. The name refers to the use of analog synthesizers in the production process, where the aim is to ''"squeeze out"'' the most interesting sounds possible.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://skweee.com/he-called-it-skweee |title=skweeelicious! » He Called It Skweee |publisher=Skweee.com |date=9 January 2009 |accessdate=18 October 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111007162522/http://skweee.com/he-called-it-skweee |archivedate=7 October 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>http://skweee.com/spin_skweee_article.PDF</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.clashmusic.com/feature/inside-skweee |title=Inside Skweee | Clash Music Exclusive Best of Clash |publisher=Clashmusic.com |date=16 September 2008 |accessdate=18 October 2011}}</ref>
Producers can vary from high-profile to new talent from the Scandinavian [[electronica]] environment.
[http://skweee.com Skweeelicious], a blog dedicated to skweee, and community sites such as MySpace and [http://nationofskweee.com Nation of Skweee] have played a major role in the distribution of skweee music and public exposure of the genre.
The major outlets of skweee music are the Swedish record label [http://www.flogstadanshall.com/ Flogsta Danshall]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.flogstadanshall.com |title=Flogsta Danshall |publisher=Flogsta Danshall |accessdate=18 October 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.myspace.com/flogstadanshall |title=Flogsta Danshall | Free Music, Tour Dates, Photos, Videos |publisher=Myspace.com |accessdate=18 October 2011}}</ref> and Finnish record label [http://harmoenia.fi Harmönia].<ref>{{cite web|author=Fi |url=http://www.myspace.com/harmoenia |title=HARMÖNIA record label | Gratis muziek, tourneedata, foto's, video's |publisher=Myspace.com |accessdate=18 October 2011}}</ref> Norwegian [[Dødpop]],<ref>{{cite web|author=NO |url=http://www.myspace.com/dodpop |title=dødpop | Gratis muziek, tourneedata, foto's, video's |publisher=Myspace.com |accessdate=18 October 2011}}</ref> Canadian [http://ancientrobot.com Ancient Robot],<ref>{{cite web|author=Un |url=http://ancientrobot.bandcamp.com/|title=Ancient Robot | |publisher=Bandcamp.com |accessdate=5 April 2013}}</ref> US Losonofono,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://losonofono.bandcamp.com |title=losonofono |publisher=Losonofono.bandcamp.com |date=14 February 2011 |accessdate=18 October 2011}}</ref> US Titched,<ref>{{cite web|author=Un |url=http://www.myspace.com/titched |title=Titched | Gratis muziek, tourneedata, foto's, video's |publisher=Myspace.com |accessdate=18 October 2011}}</ref> US Poisonous Gases,<ref>{{cite web|author=US |url=http://www.myspace.com/poisonousgases |title=POISONOUS GASES | Gratis muziek, tourneedata, foto's, video's |publisher=Myspace.com |accessdate=18 October 2011}}</ref> Spanish Lo Fi Funk,<ref>[http://www.myspace.com/lofifunk.records ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091214135721/http://www.myspace.com/lofifunk.records |date=14 December 2009 }}</ref> Finnish Mässy,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://maessy.com |title=Mässy Recordings, Helsinki Finland 2011. Skweee, Mekano-trunk, Wonky etc |publisher=Maessy.com |accessdate=18 October 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110820111543/http://maessy.com/ |archivedate=20 August 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> and French [[Mazout]]<ref>{{cite web|author=FR |url=http://www.myspace.com/disquesmazout |title=Poborsk – OUT NOW // Savio – 7" OUT JUNE | Gratis muziek, tourneedata, foto's, video's |publisher=Myspace.com |accessdate=18 October 2011}}</ref> have since been added to this family. The preferred media format of skweee enthusiasts is the 7" vinyl record. Early releases were exclusively released in this format. More recently, however, a series of 12" vinyl records, digital releases and CD compilations have been released through these outlets as well.
The increasing notability of the skweee genre has resulted in releases such as the Eero Johannes album on [[Planet Mu]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.planet-mu.com/artists/eerojohannes |title=Planet Mu Records |publisher=Planet-mu.com |accessdate=18 October 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100205000103/http://www.planet-mu.com/artists/eerojohannes |archivedate=5 February 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.xlr8r.com/features/2009/06/somewhere-nordic-skwee |title=Somewhere: Nordic Skweee |publisher=XLR8R |accessdate=18 October 2011}}</ref> and the Skweee Tooth compilation on Ramp Recordings.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://blogs.myspace.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=blog.view&friendId=35181333&blogId=491782603 |title=V/A – SKWEEE TOOTH CD & 2xLP / OUT MONDAY 1st JUNE van RAMP Recordings op Myspace |publisher=Blogs.myspace.com |date=7 October 2011 |accessdate=18 October 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140416224409/http://blogs.myspace.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=blog.view&friendId=35181333&blogId=491782603 |archivedate=16 April 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==Skweee and dubstep== Skweee has, during late 2008 and early 2009, started to influence the sound of [[dubstep]]. A thread started on the [http://dubstepforum.com/viewtopic.php?t=40320 dubstepforum] made the scene aware of skweee. Producers such as [[Rusko (musician)|Rusko]],<ref>{{cite web|author=Civil Music |url=http://civilmusic.com/buy/sing-what-you-want |title=Kotchy – Sing What You Want |publisher=Civil Music |date=1 December 2008 |accessdate=18 October 2011}}</ref> Gemmy, [[Joker (Musician)|Joker]],<ref name="discogs1">{{cite web|url=http://www.discogs.com/Joker-5-Rustie-Play-Doe-Tempered/release/1522691 |title=Joker (5) & Rustie – Play Doe / Tempered (Vinyl) at Discogs |publisher=Discogs.com |accessdate=18 October 2011}}</ref> Zomby, Rustie,<ref name="discogs1"/> among others, have given their take on the sound, resulting in several releases on the boundary between skweee and dubstep.<ref>{{cite web|author=Ralf Christensen |url=http://www.information.dk/186532 |title='Wonky' giver ny søgang i computeren |publisher=information.dk |accessdate=18 October 2011}}</ref> The gap between dubstep and skweee has been further bridged by artists such as DJ Pontificate and underground ambient artist Chohmo, as evidenced by the former's release "Skweeeal."
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070809035009/http://www.flowmagazine.net/more.php?id=45 Interview with Skweee-pioneer Pavan] * [https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2009/apr/07/skweee-8bit-hiphop-electronica John McDonnell's (The Guardian UK) blog article about skweee] * [http://skweee.com/spin_skweee_article.PDF Article in Spin Magazine (April 2009) as a PDF file] * [http://www.clashmusic.com/feature/inside-skweee Article in Clash Magazine] * [http://www.thewire.co.uk/articles/1430/ Article in The Wire] * [http://www.globalsoundtracks.com/show/10-august-2009/ Podcast featuring live recording of Harmönia vs Flogsta battle at the Norberg Festival 2009 and an interview with most of the main artists of these labels]
{{Chiptune-footer}} {{Minimal music (EDM) footer}} {{Funkmusic}} {{nerd music}}

revision.text:
{{more references|date=April 2009}} In U.S. [[broadcast law]], a '''special temporary authority''' ('''STA''') is a type of [[broadcast license]] which temporarily allows a broadcast station to operate outside of its normal technical or legal parameters. <ref name="stafcc">{{cite web|title=Emergency Antennas, Silent Stations, and Special Temporary Authority for the Broadcast Services|url=https://www.fcc.gov/media/radio/special-temporary-authority|website=Federal Communications Commission|language=en|date=13 December 2015}}</ref> In the [[Federal Communications Commission]] (FCC) station [[database]] (CDBS), broadcast STA applications have a prefix of BSTA (general), BLSTA (legal), BESTA (engineering), or BLESTA (both). STAs can also be issued for other [[telecommunication]] services under FCC [[regulation]]. Often an STA is necessary due to an unforeseen event. A station operator must exhibit why the STA is necessary and serves the public good.
A common reason to apply for STA is an equipment failure. In case a station cannot use its licensed antenna or transmission system, it can immediately continue operations using any available antenna or operating parts of existing system, as long as an STA is filed for within 24 hours. An AM station may use a [[random wire antenna]] if necessary. AM stations operating directionally are limited to 25 percent of their licensed power if their directional array fails and they must operate non-directionally under STA. If a station is evicted from its transmitter site or must move for another reason, it may also continue operating from a temporary site under the same rules, as long as it does not change or increase its coverage area or plan to permanently broadcast from that site. These rules allow stations to resume broadcasting quickly in case of a [[state of disaster]].<ref name="stafcc" />
A station may go silent entirely for up to ten days without notifying the FCC at all, and up to thirty days with only a letter of notification. A station that is or will be silent for longer than thirty days must apply for a "silent STA", which can be granted for up to six months.<ref name="stafcc" /> The FCC typically required that silence be for reasons beyond the operator's control, such as total equipment failure or loss of programming, and asked for plans to return the station to air. The commission has since started to grant silent STAs for financial reasons. Stations that are silent can also apply for an operational STA to resume broadcasting from a temporary facility, to avoid losing its license after one continuous year of silence. The one-year limit was written into the [[Telecommunications Act of 1996]] and cannot be overridden by the FCC due to extenuating circumstances.<ref>{{cite web|title=Steps to Take When A Broadcast Station Goes Silent|url=https://www.broadcastlawblog.com/2009/01/articles/steps-to-take-when-a-broadcast-station-goes-silent/|website=Broadcast Law Blog|date=29 January 2009}}</ref>
This silent/operational STA process presents a loophole in that it can be used to work around the Telecommunications Act indefinitely, and such STAs are normally granted with little oversight. In January 2018, the FCC initiated a crackdown on stations that exploit the loophole. The first high-profile case was co-owned stations [[WBVA (AM)|WBVA]] in [[Bayside, Virginia Beach, Virgin|Bayside, Virginia]] and [[WVAB]] in [[Virginia Beach, Virginia]], whose 2017 license renewals were designated for a hearing. The stations have operated under a cycle of silent and operational STAs since 2008; they applied yearly to broadcast with 30 and 6 watts, respectively, from a temporary site for several weeks before going silent for the rest of the year. Station owner [[Birach Broadcasting Corporation]] has claimed it is stuck with the temporary facilities as it has been unable to get zoning approval for a new transmitter site.<ref>{{cite news|title=FCC’s Silent Station Crackdown Targets Virginia AMs.|url=http://www.insideradio.com/free/fcc-s-silent-station-crackdown-targets-virginia-ams/article_9795caba-000e-11e8-81c1-fbf05ea20f2c.html|work=Insideradio.com|language=en}}</ref>
An STA can also be used for special events as a [[Restricted Service Licence]] is in the [[U.K.]], however this is rare. A market has developed around proprietary devices that provide live audio or video to attendees of a conference or sporting event; these devices receive a signal from a low-powered television station operating under a temporary STA in VHF [[Band I]], which is largely no longer used for broadcasting.<ref>{{cite web|title=STA Washington, DC Facility Data [example]|url=https://fccdata.org/?appid=25076f9156578c3301569a55ad85198b&facid=703507|website=FCCData}}</ref>
==References== <references />
==External links== *[http://www.fcc.gov/pshs/services/sta.html FCC STA page]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Special Temporary Authority}} [[Category:Broadcasting in the United States]] [[Category:Broadcast engineering]] [[Category:Broadcast law]]
