{{Refimprove|date=October 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2016}} {{Infobox video game | title = TOCA Race Driver 3 | image = TOCA Race Driver 3 Cover.jpg | developer = [[Codemasters]] | publisher = Codemasters | series = ''[[TOCA (series)|TOCA]]'' | platforms = [[Microsoft Windows]], [[PlayStation 2]], [[Xbox (console)|Xbox]], [[PlayStation Portable]], [[OS X]], [[Nintendo DS]] | released = '''Microsoft Windows''', '''PlayStation 2''' & '''Xbox'''
{{vgrelease|NA|22 February 2006|EU|24 February 2006|AUS|13 October 2006}}'''PlayStation Portable'''
{{vgrelease|EU|16 February 2007|AUS|23 February 2007}}'''OS X'''
{{vgrelease|NA|24 October 2008}} | genre = [[Racing game|Racing]] | modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]], [[Multiplayer video game|Multiplayer]] }} '''''TOCA Race Driver 3''''' ('''''DTM Race Driver 3''''' in Germany, '''''V8 Supercars 3''''' in Australia, '''''TOCA Race Driver 3 Challenge''''' in the PlayStation Portable version and '''''Race Driver: Create & Race''''' in the Nintendo DS version) is a [[Racing video game]] developed and published by [[Codemasters]] for [[Microsoft Windows]], [[PlayStation 2]], [[Xbox (console)|Xbox]], [[PlayStation Portable]], [[Nintendo DS]] and [[OS X]]. It is the sixth game in the [[TOCA (series)|''TOCA'' series]]. The game features several fully licensed championships, including the [[Deutsche Tourenwagen Masters|DTM]] series and [[V8 Supercar]] championship. This is the last in the series to have TOCA in its title as following on from this TOCA was dropped in favour of just Race Driver. It includes 120 Championships and 35 Types of Racing through the Championship in World Tour, Pro Career, and Free Race. Also it has Bonus Championships in different disciplines. They take place largely in the UK and Germany, though many more tracks are unlocked by winning cups in Pro Career, or by setting a lap time record on a course within Pro Career mode. Open wheel, GT, Oval racing, Rallying and Off-road racing were all featured, and can be raced in either a detailed Pro Career mode or an open-ended World Tour. Online play allows 12 and 8 players on PlayStation 2 and Xbox, respectively. Currently, it is the only racing simulator for PlayStation 2 with an online racing mode. For the PC up to 12 players could race together with the built-in Gamespy Server or by using a LAN. When Gamespy closed in 2014 Online Multiplayer was subsequently made possible using the Free Tunngle Network. But the Tunngle Network was shutdown at 30.04.2018 due to pending requirements of the new European [[General Data Protection Regulation]]. However, Cross-Platform Online Racing was still possible in 2018 using the Openspy Server. The game received good reviews, frequently being compared favorably to ''[[Gran Turismo 4]]'' and ''[[Forza Motorsport]]'', in the aspects of cars on track, collision and wear damage. Custom tuning of suspension components for handling and gear ratios, and including braking ratio front to rear. A more through tuning setup for a race car was allowable more so then in a driving simulator like [[Gran Turismo 4]], since TOCA Race Driver 3 was a racing simulator. The game features many real-life competitions, including British GT, DTM, IRL and V8 Supercars, as well as a Vintage series, other GT series, and Rally. The [[Williams FW27|Formula Williams FW27]] is the featured car of the Formula 1 series in the game. ==Reception== {{Video game reviews | PC = true | PS2 = true | PSP = true | XBOX = true | na = true | Edge_PC = 8/10{{cite journal |author=Edge staff |title=TOCA Race Driver 3 (PC, PS2, Xbox) |magazine=[[Edge (magazine)|Edge]] |issue=160 |date=March 2006 |page=87}} | Edge_PS2 = 8/10 | Edge_XBOX = |accessdate=25 August 2015}} }} The game received "generally favorable reviews" on all platforms according to video game [[review aggregator]] [[Metacritic]]. In Japan, where the PS2 version got a port on January 24, 2008,{{cite web |url=http://www.famitsu.com/cominy/?m=pc&a=page_h_title&title_id=11636 |title=TOCA レース ドライバー 3 ジ アルティメット レーシング シミュレーター |language=Japanese |publisher=''[[Famitsu]]'' |accessdate=29 February 2016}} ''[[Famitsu]]'' gave it a score of all four sevens for a total of 28 out of 40. ==See also== * [[V8 Supercars in video games]] {{clear}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *{{moby game|id=/toca-race-driver-3}} *{{moby game|id=psp/toca-race-driver-3-challenge|name=''TOCA Race Driver 3 Challenge''}} {{TOCA Touring Car series}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Toca Race Driver 3}} [[Category:2006 video games]] [[Category:Codemasters games]] [[Category:PlayStation 2 games]] [[Category:PlayStation Portable games]] [[Category:Racing video games set in the United States]] [[Category:Sports video games set in Germany]] [[Category:Video games developed in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Video games set in Australia]] [[Category:Video games set in the Czech Republic]] [[Category:Video games set in Germany]] [[Category:Video games set in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Windows games]] [[Category:Xbox games]] [[Category:TOCA]] [[Category:Supercars Championship]] [[Category:Multiplayer and single-player video games]] [[Category:Feral Interactive games]]

page.title: The Best Page in the Universe

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contributions/174.95.218.67|174.95.218.67]] ([[User talk:174.95.218.67|talk]]) ([[WP:HG|HG]]) (3.3.5)
revision.text:
{{italic title}} {{Infobox Website | name = ''The Best Page in the Universe'' | favicon = | logo = | screenshot = | caption = | url = [http://maddox.xmission.com/ maddox.xmission.com] | commercial = No | type = [[Satire]]
[[Fratire]] | registration = None | owner = [[Maddox (writer)|Maddox]] | author = Maddox (George Ouzounian) | launch date = 1997 | current status = Active | revenue = Unknown }} '''''The Best Page in the Universe''''' is a [[personal web page|personal]] [[satire|satirical]] [[humor]] [[website]] created by [[Maddox (writer)|George Ouzounian]], better known as Maddox, of [[Salt Lake City, Utah]]. Launched in 1997 without any high expectations, the website became known by [[word of mouth]]. ==History and status== ''The Best Page in the Universe'' originated from a text document that Maddox wrote in 1996"[http://www.salon.com/mwt/feature/2006/06/02/maddox_qa/ It's a man's world]." ''[[Salon (magazine)|Salon]]'' aptly named "fifty things that piss me off!" He gave the list to several people on [[EFnet]]'s #coders, and the positive response led him to create the website. Maddox decided to name his site ''The Best Page in the Universe'' despite his knowledge that at the time [[Yahoo!]] blocked sites with the phrase "the best" in the title from inclusion in its search engine.Maddox. [http://maddox.xmission.com/c.cgi?u=100million_stats "100 million faces rocked"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050729091647/http://maddox.xmission.com/c.cgi?u=100million_stats |date=2005-07-29 }}. ''The Best Page in the Universe''. March 18, 2005 On July 15, 2009, [[Xmission.com]], an [[ISP]] which hosts ''The Best Page in the Universe'' among other Utah clients, had an [[Alexa Internet|Alexa]] rank of about 16,000, declining to 77,000 by June 2017[http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/xmission.com XMission.com ranking on Alexa.com]. TheBestPageInTheUniverse.net, an alternate domain for Maddox's website, had an Alexa rank of about 33,000 in 2009, and 180,000 in 2017.[http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/TheBestPageInTheUniverse.net Thebestpageintheuniverse.net's rating on Alexa.com] Maddox himself wrote an article in 2002 illustrating that despite all traffic being generated by word-of-mouth alone, his site was still ranked ahead of major corporations such as [[McDonald's]] and [[Pepsi]], who spend millions of dollars on advertising every year. He launched a competition for people to send him cartoons about himself or his website, most of which are attacks about emails for "more updates." Later, he parodied this himself by stating that now that he's finished with the comic book, he'd be able to "Not update the site more regularly." Entries included a depiction of Maddox leaping out of a computer monitor and smashing two fans' faces together and a comic strip of a boy checking the website for new content only to find a cartoon of himself that he had posted ten seconds earlier.Maddox. [https://web.archive.org/web/20050325084450/http://maddox.xmission.com/c.cgi?u=book "Holy shit! I'm writing a book!"]. February 19, 2005. ''The Best Page in the Universe''. (Archive.org).Kiyan, Randy. [http://www.thebestpageintheuniverse.net/c.cgi?u=weekly_sub1 "Week of 11/01/05"]. ''The Best Page in the Universe''. November 1, 2005.Horus. [http://www.thebestpageintheuniverse.net/c.cgi?u=weekly_sub5 "Weekly Submission"]. ''The Best Page in the Universe''. November 2005. ==Format and content== ''The Best Page in the Universe'''s layout was made sparse primarily to reduce bandwidth costs. Maddox also stated the sparsity protested the many websites containing "fancy [[HTML]]" but lacking substantial content.{{Cite web|url = http://www.thebestpageintheuniverse.net/c.cgi?u=faq|title = The Best Page In The Universe: FAQ|website = www.thebestpageintheuniverse.net|access-date = 2016-03-30}} The page is headed with an image of Maddox's face superimposed over a bust of [[Che Guevara]]. In the image, Maddox is wearing a [[beret]] emblazoned with the [[Jolly Roger]], and an eye patch. Maddox uses this image as a parody of the revolutionary icon. Maddox says that Che Guevara is remembered as "Che the revolutionary," not "Che the [[pinko]]",Maddox. [http://www.thebestpageintheuniverse.net/c.cgi?u=faq "The Best Page in the Universe: FAQ"] and claims to be neither [[socialism|socialist]] nor [[communism|communist]]. Instead, he often proclaims himself to be a pirate, and typically portrays himself as such in his articles and artwork.{{Cite web|url=http://www.thebestpageintheuniverse.net/c.cgi?u=faq|title=The Best Page In The Universe: FAQ|website=www.thebestpageintheuniverse.net|access-date=2016-03-30}} Maddox has compared reading black text on a white background to "staring at a light bulb." The site uses large, light-colored text on a black background to, in the stated opinion of Maddox, reduce strain on the eyes. The site contains advertisements only for itself: it sells merchandise, such as stickers and apparel, that bear phrases from its articles.{{cite web|author=Maddox|url=http://store.theworstpageintheuniverse.com/|title=The Best Store in the Universe}} Maddox chose to not use advertisements because he thought they could end up censoring him by dropping ads.Maddox. [http://www.thebestpageintheuniverse.net/c.cgi?u=banners "Banners Blow!"] ''The Best Page in the Universe''. July 9, 2000. Many of Maddox's articles include MS Paint illustrations, with touch up done in Photoshop. Images include elderly people being fired into the [[Sun]], hippies being killed, and Maddox's testicles drawn larger than basketballs. Maddox maintains a section in which he criticizes hate mail his website has generated. When posting his replies he breaks the e-mail down and ridicules points which use [[Fallacy|fallacious]] [[logic]] and also corrects grammatical or orthographical errors. The site contains several "hidden pages", many of which are unfinished works or first drafts of articles that were moved around.[https://web.archive.org/web/20071109010354/http://www.maddoxaddicts.com/secrets.php "Maddox Addicts :: Secrets"]. Maddox Addicts ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{wikiquote}} * {{Official website|http://maddox.xmission.com/}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Best Page In The Universe, The}} [[Category:Internet properties established in 1997]] [[Category:Comedy websites]] [[Category:Internet memes]] [[Category:Entertainment websites]]

{{unreferenced|date=December 2014}} {{Infobox album | name = The Best Of TV Quiz & Game Show Themes | type = compilation | artist = various artists | cover = The Best of TV Quiz & Game Show Themes.jpg | alt = | released = 2000 | recorded = | venue = | studio = | genre = Television themes | length = | label = [[Varèse Sarabande]]/[[Universal Music Group|Universal Records]] | producer = | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = | next_year = }} '''''The Best of TV Quiz & Game Show Themes''''' was the 2000 follow-up to the bestselling ''[[Classic TV Game Show Themes]]'' CD, released by [[Varèse Sarabande]]. Like the original, the CD contained 20 tracks.
==Track listing==
# [[Match Game]] - "[[A Swingin' Safari]]" - [[Bert Kaempfert]] (3:06) # [[Password (game)|Password]] - "You Know the Password" - [[Bob Cobert]] (2:10) # [[To Tell The Truth]] - [[Bob Cobert]] (2:10) # [[Beat the Clock]] - "Subway Polka" - Harry Geller and his Orchestra (2:37) # [[The Price Is Right (1956 U.S. game show)|The Price Is Right]] - "Window Shopping" - [[Bob Cobert]] (1:41) # [[What's My Line?]] - Score Productions (2:02) # [[The Hollywood Squares]] - "Merrill's and Bob's Theme" - William Loose (2:48) # [[The Joker's Wild]] - "The Savers" - Gershon Kingsley & Jean-Jacques Perry (1:43) # [[Monopoly (game show)|Monopoly]] - [[Mort Lindsey]] (2:03) # [[Let's Make a Deal]] - "On With the Show" - [[Sheldon Allman]] & Marilyn Hall (1:31) # [[Wheel of Fortune (US daytime game show)|Wheel of Fortune]] - "Big Wheels" - [[Alan Thicke]] (2:17) # [[Tattletales]] - "Tell Those Tales" - Score Productions (2:50) # [[Blockbusters (US game show)|Blockbusters]] - "California Gold Rush" - [[Bob Cobert]] (2:22) # [[Break the Bank (1976)|Break the Bank]] - "Hustle The Bank" - Stuart Zachary Levin (2:45) # [[The Gong Show]] - "Hitting the Gong" - [[Chuck Barris]] (1:35) # [[The Diamond Head Game]] - "Diamond Head" - [[Alan Thicke]] (2:01) # [[Pyramid (game show)|The $10,000 Pyramid]] - "Tuning Up" - Ken Aldin (3:03) # [[High Rollers]] - "Bubble Gum" - Robert A. Israel (1:25) # [[Split Second (game show)|Split Second]] - "Get Wacky" - Stan Worth (2:15) # [[Rock & Roll Jeopardy!]] (also used occasionally for the [[Jeopardy! Teen Tournament]]) - Steve Kaplan & Douglas Mackaskill (2:15)
==See also== * ''[[Classic TV Game Show Themes]]''

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2017}} {{Use British English|date=August 2017}} '''Trailblazer''' is an independent British publisher of travel, trekking and railway route-guides. Started by author [[Bryn Thomas]]<ref>[http://www.owg.org.uk/profiles/brynthomas/index.html OWG profile: Bryn Thomas<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929094607/http://www.owg.org.uk/profiles/brynthomas/index.html |date=29 September 2007 }}</ref> it was originally synonymous with the ''Trans Siberian Handbook'', which for years was the only guide to crossing Asia by rail and remains much respected.<ref>/http://www.seat61.com/Trans-Siberian.htm</ref><ref>[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/1873756704 Amazon.co.uk: Trans-Siberian Handbook (Trailblazeer): Books: Bryn Thomas<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
The company now publishes guides to [[long-distance footpaths in the United Kingdom]], and [[hiking]] and [[adventure tourism]] guides to destinations elsewhere.
The publisher should not be confused with [[Trailblazer Travel Books]], a series of recreational guides for the Hawaiian Islands, Sierra Nevada, and San Francisco, which are published by California-based Diamond Valley Company.
==External links== * [http://www.trailblazer-guides.com/ Official Trailblazer website]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Trailblazer (Travel)}} [[Category:Travel guide books]] [[Category:Walking in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Hiking]] [[Category:Book publishing companies of the United Kingdom]]

revision.text:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:Twisted (''Star Trek: Voyager'')}} {{Infobox television episode | title = Twisted | series = [[Star Trek: Voyager]] | image = | caption = ''[[USS Voyager (Star Trek)|Voyager]]'' is affected by a spatial distortion ring. | season = 2 | episode = 6 | airdate = {{Start date|1995|10|02}} | production = 119 | teleplay = [[Kenneth Biller]] | story = [[Arnold Rudnick]]
[[Rich Hosek]] | director = [[Kim Friedman]] | music = [[Jay Chattaway]] | guests = * [[Larry Hankin]] - Gaunt Gary * [[Judy Geeson]] - Sandrine * [[Tom Virtue]] - Walter Baxter * [[Terry Correll]] - Crewman | prev = [[Non Sequitur (Star Trek: Voyager)|Non Sequitur]] | next = [[Parturition (Star Trek: Voyager)|Parturition]] | episode_list = List of Star Trek: Voyager episodes | season_article = Star Trek: Voyager (season 2) }} __NOTOC__ "'''Twisted'''" is the 22nd episode of ''[[Star Trek: Voyager]]'', the sixth episode in the [[Star Trek: Voyager (season 2)|second season]]. ==Plot== ''[[USS Voyager (Star Trek)|Voyager]]'' encounters a strange energy field during a surprise party on the holodeck for [[Kes (Star Trek)|Kes]]'s second birthday. Many members of the crew are at the party, including [[Kathryn Janeway|Captain Janeway]] and [[Doctor (Star Trek)|The Doctor]], who is acting as their bartender. Eventually the ship becomes stuck in the field, causing the internal communications system on board ''Voyager'' to fail. Unable to communicate with [[Tuvok]], who is acting captain during the party, the crew end the party early and attempt to return to their posts, however the ship's layout has mysteriously changed and they are unable to find their way. The crew eventually become separated and hopelessly lost within the labyrinthine corridors. Meanwhile, The Doctor becomes unable to return himself to sickbay, and finds himself amorously pursued by the hologram Sandrine. During the exploration, [[Neelix]] once more becomes jealous of [[Tom Paris]]'s relationship with Kes; he goes on to demand to know more about her friendships with other male officers. When she becomes angry and refuses to discuss her feelings with him, he goes to [[Chakotay]] for advice. Chakotay tells him that jealousy is natural, but that he must try to control himself for the sake of his relationship with Kes. The crew, including Tuvok, who has left the bridge and become similarly lost, all find themselves back at the holodeck. They organize themselves in an attempt to reach crucial areas of the ship such as engineering and the bridge; [[B'Elanna Torres|B'Elanna]] and Paris are successful in reaching engineering, but when they try to transport to the bridge they find themselves back at the holodeck. Meanwhile, Janeway becomes delirious after coming into direct contact with the energy field, which is penetrating further into the ship, and is brought to the holodeck by [[Harry Kim (Star Trek)|Harry Kim]] in the hope that The Doctor can help her. B'Elanna returns to Engineering and makes an attempt to stop the field with a ship-wide energy burst, but this only makes the field envelop the ship at an accelerated rate. With the holodeck as the last refuge, the crew gathers there, and Tuvok suggests that the most logical course of action is to simply do nothing, as any attempt to stop it has only made the situation worse, and they so far have no evidence that being engulfed by the field is fatal. They do as Tuvok suggests and neither the crew nor the ship is harmed by passing through the field. Janeway is returned to health and surmises that the energy field was somehow sentient and trying to communicate with them – her theory is backed by the fact that the entire ship's memory had been downloaded and that 20 billion gigaquads of data have been uploaded to ''Voyager''{{'}}s computer. ==Production== "Twisted" was extensively rewritten prior to being shot, and was for a time rumored to be so bad that it would never be aired, based largely on comments that [[Robert Picardo]] made at several fan conventions.[[Cinefantastique]], Vol. 27, No. 4/5, p. 79 The episode originally underran its time significantly, and several scenes had to be invented to extend its length, most significantly the subplot involving The Doctor being pursued by Sandrine.David McIntee (March 9, 2000) ''Delta Quadrant - The Unofficial Guide to Voyager'', Virgin Books, {{ISBN|0753504367}}, p. 60 Script writer [[Michael Piller]] went on to voice criticisms about Neelix's subplot in this episode; he felt that the character should not be constantly portrayed as a 'buffoon', and attempting to correct the issues that he saw and resolve the subplot in question with the following episode, [[Parturition (Star Trek: Voyager)|"Parturition"]].Edward Gross and Mark A. Altman (June 1996) ''Captains' Logs Supplemental - The Unauthorized Guide to the New Trek Voyages'', Little Brown & Co., {{ISBN|0316883549}} Reviewers [[Lance Parkin]] and Mark Jones complained that the massive data deposit of 20 billion gigaquads was never explained or referred to again, leading to frustration as to why it was ever mentioned in the first place.{{cite book|last=Jones|first=Mark|last2=Parkin|first2=Lance|year=2003|title=Beyond the Final Frontier: An Unauthorised Review of the Trek Universe on Television and Film|publisher=Contender Books|location=London|isbn=978-1-84357-080-6|page=285}} ==Reception== TV.com lists "Twisted" with a rating of 7.9/10 as of 2018, based on 179 votes.[http://www.tv.com/shows/star-trek-voyager/twisted-10661/] It had a Nielsen rating of 5.6 points when it was broadcast in 1995.[http://users.telenet.be/WebTrek/Voy/Ratings/ratings.html] ==See also== {{portal|Star Trek}} *[[List of Star Trek: Voyager episodes|List of ''Star Trek: Voyager'' episodes]] *"[["—And He Built a Crooked House—"]]", [[Robert A. Heinlein]] short story in which a house becomes four-dimensional as a result of an earthquake, with effects similar to this episode. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{wikiquote|Star Trek: Voyager#Twisted .5B2.6.5D|Twisted}} * {{IMDb title|id=0709001|title=Twisted}} * {{tv.com episode|star-trek-voyager/twisted-10661|Twisted}} {{Memoryalpha|Twisted}} {{StarTrek.com link|VOY|68856|Twisted}} {{Star Trek: Voyager episodes|2}} {{Use mdy dates|date=November 2017}} [[Category:Star Trek: Voyager (season 2) episodes]] [[Category:1995 American television episodes]] [[Category:Holography in television]]

revision.comment: Bot: removing [[User:FrescoBot/Misplaced invisible LTR marks|misplaced invisible LTR marks]]
revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{Refimprove|date=July 2009}} {{Orphan|date=February 2009}} }} '''Universal Circulating Music Library''' was a music publishers' activity established in the [[United Kingdom]] in the 1850s and 1860s.For a general history of Circulating Music Libraries see Alec Hyatt King, 'Music Circulating Libraries in Britain' in ''The Musical Times'', Vol. 119, No. 1620 (Feb., 1978), pp. 134-138. By the 1920s no significant such circulating libraries by music publishers survived, most probably due to reduced demand (the interested public would just buy the music they were interested in). In terms of the housed collections/music in such "libraries" run by publishers, it is probably fair to say that most was lost, with only some still being in music publisher's archives. ==Messrs. Schuermann & Co.== Messrs. Schuermann & Co. were probably the first music publisher in the [[United Kingdom]] to start a ''Universal Circulating Music Library'' in 1855.See announcement in ''The Musical Times and Singing Class Circular'', Vol. 6, No. 139 (Feb. 15, 1855), p. 313 An announcement at the time stated: 'Many of our readers will be glad to have their attention directed towards the very comprehensive Music Library which has been formed by Messrs. Schuermann & Co., of 72, Newgate-street. The catalogue contains more than 42,042 separately numbered works, embracing almost every English and Foreign publication, under various headings and subdivisions. Libraries of reference are of such absolute necessity to all students, especially to the musician, that several attempts have been made to satisfy the want; but most of these labor under the serious disadvantage of being confined to either one class of musical works, or—as in the case of the [[British Museum]]—of being available only to those who can go from home to study. Messrs. Schuermann’s arrangements allow of a very liberal supply of works at the subscriber’s private residence, And the small annual cost would be well bestowed even by those who ultimately intend to purchase a private library for their own use, because it affords so complete an oppoortunity of examining the merits of a work previously to purchase. A very handsomely printed catalogue may be purchased at small cost; its perusal will fully prove the great outlay at which the proprietors have got together this collection.'Announcement in ''The Musical Times and Singing Class Circular'', Vol. 6, No. 139 (Feb. 15, 1855), p. 313 ==Novello, Ewer & Co.== The ''Universal Circulating Music Library'' provided by Novello, Ewer & Co. dates back to 1867/68. The preface of the first catalogue states:
The Universal Circulating Music Library:

This Library, which was established, and has been most successfully carried on since 1859, by Messrs. Ewer and Co., has been purchased by Messr. Novello and Co., and will be continued by them under the style of Novello, Ewer and Co.

In addition to the works named in the Library Catalogue, the whole of the publications of Messr. Novello, Ewer and Co. will be available to Subscribers; and neither expense nor exertion will be spared to make the Library still more complete.

A Supplement is now added to the present Catalogue, which makes the collection the largest and most valuable ever offered to the public. All New Music (Foreign or English) of merit will be added to the Library as soon as published, and every endeavour will be made to supply the wants of Subscribers immediately on application.

August, 1867.Catalogue of the Universal Circulating Music Library. [With a supplement.], London: Novello, Ewer & Co., 1868[?], preface, not numbered
The terms of subscription and the regulations of use are given on the next page. ==Notes== {{Reflist|2}} ==Further reading== * William C. Smith, 'Music Publishing in the British Isles from the Beginnings until the Middle of the Nineteenth Century', 2nd edn., Oxford: Basil Blackwell, 1970. * Alec Hyatt King 'Music Circulating Libraries in Britain', in 'The Musical Times', Vol. 119, No. 1620 (Feb., 1978), pp. 134–138. * John A. Parkinson, 'Victorian Music Publishers: An Annotated List' (Detroit Studies in Music Bibliography, 64) Warren, Mich.: 1990. [[Category:Music publishing]] [[Category:Music libraries]] [[Category:Music organisations based in the United Kingdom]]

revision.comment: I updated the numbers on the size of the Australian video game development industry.
revision.text:
{{Use Australian English|date=June 2017}}
The video game industry in Australia is worth $2.96 billion annually as of 2016, inclusive of traditional retail and digital sales.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2017/02/28/australian-video-game-industry-nudges-3-billion-for-2016|title=Australian Video Game Industry Nudges $3 Billion for 2016|last=Reilly|first=Luke|date=2017-02-27|website=IGN|language=en-US|access-date=2017-06-02}}</ref> A survey completed in 2017 indicated that game development in Australia employed 928 people.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=https://igea.net/2018/01/australian-game-developers-march-generating-118-5m-spite-limited-recognition-support/|title=Australian Video Game Development Industry Snapshot, FY 2016-17}}</ref> In fiscal year 2016-17, revenue from Australian game developers was approximately $118.5 million, 80 percent of which was from overseas sales.<ref name=":3" />
The industry body for video games in Australia is the [[Interactive Games & Entertainment Association]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://business.scoop.co.nz/2017/03/08/nz-video-games-industry-revenues-race-ahead-to-424m-in-2016/|title=Scoop Business » NZ video games industry revenues race ahead to $424M in 2016|language=en|access-date=2017-06-02}}</ref> The Game Developers Association of Australia supports video game development.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.gdaa.com.au/about-us-2/|title=About Us – Game Developers' Association of Australia|website=www.gdaa.com.au|language=en|access-date=2017-06-02}}</ref>
Video game retailers in Australia include [[EB Games Australia|EB Games]] and [[Gametraders]]. Video games are also sold at department stores like [[Big W]] and [[Target Australia|Target]].
== History == [[Beam Software]] was one of the first Australian game development studios to achieve global success, with a [[text adventure]] adaption of [[The Hobbit (1982 video game)|The Hobbit]] released in 1982 for the [[ZX Spectrum]]. The company went on to produce other successful titles including [[The Way of the Exploding Fist]] for [[Commodore 64]] in 1985 and [[Le Mans 24 Hours video games|Le Mans]] for the [[Dreamcast|SEGA Dreamcast]] in 2001. [[Ozisoft]], a major distributor of games, was established in 1982.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Brand|first=Jeffery E.|date=2008|title=History of Game Development in Australia|url=https://2015.acmi.net.au/media/2457231/games_history_australia.pdf|journal=Multimedia Victoria|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref>
Other early game development studios in Australia include [[Strategic Studies Group|SSG]], who developed [[Reach for the Stars (video game)|Reach for the Stars]] in 1983, and [[Micro Forté]], founded by [[John De Margheriti]] in 1985.
[[John De Margheriti]] later established the [[Academy of Interactive Entertainment]] (AIE) in 1996 and founded the Game Developers Association of Australia (GDAA) in 1999. The first president of the GDAA was Adam Lancman, who had previously worked at [[Beam Software]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://playitagainproject.org/creators/adam-lancman/|title=Adam Lancman {{!}} Play It Again|website=playitagainproject.org|language=en|access-date=2017-06-01}}</ref>
[[Gameswizards|The Game Wizards]], an Australian video game retailer, was established in 1990. It was the first retailer to sell games online in Australia when it set up its website in 1997. In 2007, the company's 22 stores were acquired by [[Game (retailer)|GAME]] and re-branded. By 2009 GAME Australia had expanded to over 100 stores.<ref name=":4">{{Cite news|url=http://www.mcvpacific.com/news/read/a-history-of-game/096272|title=A history of GAME|work=MCV Pacific|access-date=2017-06-02}}</ref>
EB Games entered the market as a video game retailer in 1997.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://connectonline.asic.gov.au/RegistrySearch/faces/landing/SearchRegisters.jspx?_adf.ctrl-state=z3rmle2wc_4|title=ASIC Company Search Results|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref>
In 2002, the Interactive Entertainment Association of Australia (IEAA) was established<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://connectonline.asic.gov.au/RegistrySearch/faces/landing/panelSearch.jspx?searchText=101586958&searchType=OrgAndBusNm&_adf.ctrl-state=158ae52j5f_15|title=Search Results – Organisations and Business Names|website=connectonline.asic.gov.au|language=en-AU|access-date=2017-06-01}}</ref> as an [[Trade association|industry association]] for publishers, distributors and marketers of video games.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.igea.net/about/|title=About – IGEA|work=IGEA|access-date=2017-06-01|language=en-US}}</ref> A research report published by the association in 2005 found that the 76 per cent of households had a device for playing video games, 38 per cent of gamers were female and the average age of a gamer was 24.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Brand|first=Jeffery E.|date=2005|title=GamePlay Australia 2005|url=http://www.igea.net/wp-content/uploads/2009/08/GamePlay_Aust_2005.pdf|journal=Interactive Entertainment Association of Australia|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> The IEAA was later renamed the [[Interactive Games & Entertainment Association]] (IGEA).<ref name=":1" />
In 2005, the top three games by units sold were [[Gran Turismo 4]], [[Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas|GTA: San Andreas]] and [[Pokémon Emerald]].<ref name=":1" /> The most popular game genres were [[Strategy video game|strategy]], [[Adventure game|adventure]] and [[Action game|action]].<ref name=":1" />
[[Team Bondi]], a Sydney-based [[Independent business|independent]] [[Third-party developer|third-party]] [[Video game developer|game developer]], was founded in 2003.<ref name="FoundationDate">{{cite web|author=Tom Bramwell |url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/news190705bondips3 |title=Team Bondi's PS3 title named News – PlayStation 3 – Page 1 |publisher=Eurogamer.net |date=19 July 2005 |accessdate=24 May 2011}}</ref> The studio was responsible for the [[Microsoft Windows]], [[Xbox 360]] and [[PlayStation 3]] title ''[[L.A. Noire]]'', published by [[Multinational corporation|multinational]] video game developer and publisher [[Rockstar Games]] (also popular for the ''[[Grand Theft Auto]]'' series). ''L.A. Noire'' was both a critical and commercial success, with over 5 million sales. Despite this, Team Bondi was [[Liquidation|wound up]] on 5 October 2011.<ref name="Edge_Oct_5">{{cite web|author=Nathan Brown |url=http://www.next-gen.biz/news/team-bondi-close |title=Team Bondi to close – Edge Magazine |publisher=Next-gen.biz |date= |accessdate=25 June 2012}}</ref>
Between 2005 and 2015, a number of other large studios operating in Australia shut down including KMM Brisbane, [[Pandemic Studios]], [[Krome Studios]], [[THQ]], [[Visceral Games]] and [[2K Australia]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.kotaku.com.au/2015/04/2k-australia-in-canberra-closes-its-doors/|title=2K Australia In Canberra Closes Its Doors|last=Serrels|first=Mark|access-date=2017-06-02}}</ref><ref name=":3" />
During the same period, smaller game developers were having success with [[mobile game]]s. In 2010, [[Halfbrick Studios|Halfbrick]], a studio based in Brisbane, released [[Fruit Ninja]] which has since been downloaded over a billion times. Other notable mobile games developed in Australia include [[Crossy Road]] and [[Framed (video game)|Framed]]. In October 2015, half of the top 10 mobile games in the [[App store|App Store]] were Australian made.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/triplej/programs/hack/the-long-and-narrow-road-to-the-app-store/7496908|title=Anything but Pokemon: The long and narrow road to the App Store|last=Purtill|first=James|date=2016-07-19|work=triple j|access-date=2017-06-02|language=en}}</ref>
EB Games held the first [[EB Games Expo|EB Expo]] video game convention at the [[Gold Coast Convention and Exhibition Centre]] in 2011.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.mcvpacific.com/news/read/eb-expo-kicks-off-tomorrow/086414|title=EB EXPO kicks off tomorrow!|work=MCV Pacific|access-date=2017-06-02}}</ref> The expo was attended by over 10,000 people.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.mcvpacific.com/news/read/wrap-up-of-the-eb-expo/086565|title=Wrap up of the EB EXPO|last=|first=|date=|website=MCV Pacific|access-date=}}</ref> The expo moved to the [[Sydney Showground (Olympic Park)|Sydney Showground]] for 2012 and was held there annually until the expo returned to the [[Gold Coast, Queensland|Gold Coast]] in 2017. 36,750 people attended the expo in 2015.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://stateofplay.co.nz/sydneys-eb-expo-2015-breaks-last-years-attendance-record/|title=Sydney’s EB Expo 2015 breaks last year’s attendance record|date=2015-10-10|work=Vic B'Stard's State of Play|access-date=2017-06-02|language=en-AU}}</ref>
At [[History of PAX|PAX Prime 2012]], it was announced that [[PAX (event)|PAX]] would expand internationally to Australia. [[PAX Australia]] was held for the first time in 2013 at the [[Melbourne Showgrounds]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.kotaku.com.au/2012/09/pax-australia-is-heading-to-melbourne/|title=PAX Australia Is Heading To Melbourne|last=Serrels|first=Mark|access-date=2017-06-02|language=en}}</ref> The annual event remains the only PAX event held out side of the United States.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/technology/gadgets-on-the-go/pax-australia-plays-its-cards-right-20161107-gsjkhm.html|title=PAX Australia plays its cards right|last=Turner|first=Adam|date=2016-11-07|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|access-date=2017-06-02|language=en-US}}</ref>
On 14 May 2012 GAME, which had since downsized to 26 stores,<ref name=":4" /> went into administration and subsequently closed down.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.mcvpacific.com/news/read/pwc-talks-about-game-s-administration-process/095988|title=PwC talks about GAME's administration process|work=MCV Pacific|access-date=2017-06-02}}</ref>
The Digital Australia 2012 report, published by the IGEA, found that female participation in video gaming had risen to 48 per cent and the average age of an Australian video gamer had hit 32.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Brand|first=Jeffery E.|date=2012|title=Digital Australia 2012|url=http://www.igea.net/wp-content/uploads/2011/10/DA12FinalLinkVideo.pdf|journal=Interactive Games & Entertainment Association|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> Traditional retail sales of video games in Australia during 2012 were $1.16 Billion; digital sales were estimated at $620 Million.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.computerworld.com.au/mediareleases/15759/video-games-industry-records-1161-billion-sales/|title=Video games industry records $1.161 billion sales in 2012 – Media Releases – Computerworld|website=Computerworld|access-date=2017-06-03}}</ref>
In 2013, Australia was ranked 14th in the world in terms of gaming revenues.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://newzoo.com/insights/infographics/australia-ranks-number-one-in-the-world-in-average-spend-on-ipad-games/|title=Australian games market: Infographic|date=December 5, 2013|website=Newzoo|publisher=Newzoo|accessdate=4 April 2017}}</ref>
On 22 June 2015 the [[Australian Senate]] commenced an inquiry into the future of Australia's video game development industry.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.aph.gov.au/Parliamentary_Business/Committees/Senate/Environment_and_Communications/Video_game_industry/Terms_of_Reference|title=Terms of Reference|last=7111;|first=corporateName=Commonwealth Parliament; address=Parliament House, Canberra, ACT, 2600; contact=+61 2 6277|website=www.aph.gov.au|language=en-AU|access-date=2017-06-02}}</ref> The subsequent report was tabled on 29 April 2016.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.aph.gov.au/Parliamentary_Business/Committees/Senate/Environment_and_Communications/Video_game_industry/Report|title=Report|last=7111;|first=corporateName=Commonwealth Parliament; address=Parliament House, Canberra, ACT, 2600; contact=+61 2 6277|website=www.aph.gov.au|language=en-AU|access-date=2017-06-02}}</ref>
== Censorship == <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:HYPER Magazine Issue 2 1993 Page 9 - "Classified Information".jpg|250px|thumb|right|An article from a 1993 issue of ''[[Hyper (magazine)|Hyper]]'' summarising all of the video game classifications and reporting on a government conference that took place concerning the classifications.]] --> Video games could not be designated an adults only or 18+ rating in Australia until 1 January 2013.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=https://www.gizmodo.com.au/2013/01/r18-ratings-for-video-games-are-now-live-in-australia/|title=R18+ Ratings For Video Games Are Now Live In Australia|last=Hopewell|first=Luke|access-date=2017-06-01}}</ref> An R18+ classification rating has been available for this purpose for other forms of media since the introduction of the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Act 1995. Prior to 1 January 2013, a video game that had content deemed unsuitable for persons under the age of 18 would be 'Refused Classification' by the [[Australian Classification Board]] (ACB) under this act.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2013/jun/26/saints-row-4-censorship-australia |title=Australia's ban of Saints Row 4 is emblematic of a conservative culture | Dan Golding | Comment is free |publisher=theguardian.com |date=2007-09-28 |accessdate=2013-11-12}}</ref> Classification of video games is mandatory in Australia and material refused classification is legally banned from sale, hire or import.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.classification.gov.au/Public/Resources/Pages/Parents.aspx|title=Parents {{!}} Australian Classification|website=www.classification.gov.au|language=en-au|access-date=2017-06-01}}</ref>
Notable video games that were refused classification by the ACB prior to the introduction of an R18+ for video games include: [[Duke Nukem 3D]], [[Grand Theft Auto III]], [[Grand Theft Auto: Vice City]], [[Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas]], [[Grand Theft Auto IV]], [[Fallout 3]], [[Left 4 Dead 2]], [[Mortal Kombat (2011 video game)|Mortal Kombat (2011)]] and [[The House of the Dead: Overkill|The House of the Dead: Overkill Extended Cut]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|date=2017-05-20|title=List of banned video games in Australia|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=List_of_banned_video_games_in_Australia&oldid=781324380|journal=Wikipedia|language=en}}</ref> Most of these games were subsequently modified by the publishers and later reclassified MA15+ and made available for sale in Australia.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gamespot.com/articles/fallout-3-unbanned-in-australia/1100-6195752/|title=Fallout 3 unbanned in Australia|last=Ramsay|first=Randolph|date=2008-08-12|website=GameSpot|language=en-US|access-date=2017-06-01}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.pcgamer.com/left-4-dead-2-is-now-legal-in-australia-in-its-full-uncensored-glory/|title=Left 4 Dead 2 is now legal in Australia in its full, uncensored glory|work=pcgamer|access-date=2017-06-01|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.kotaku.com.au/2008/05/australian_and_unmodified_gta_iv_compared/|title=What Was Cut? Australian And Unmodified GTA IV Compared|last=Booker|first=Logan|access-date=2017-06-01|language=en}}</ref>
On 22 July 2011, the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General agreed in-principle to introduce legislation that would allow video games to be classified R18+.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/digital-life/games/historic-agreement-on-r18-video-games-20110722-1hs78.html|title='Historic agreement' on R18+ video games|last=Moses|first=Asher|date=2011-07-22|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|access-date=2017-06-01|last2=Grubb|first2=Ben|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.gamesindustry.biz/articles/2011-07-22-australia-introduces-r18-certificate-for-games|title=Australia introduces R18+ certificate for games|work=GamesIndustry.biz|access-date=2017-06-01|language=en}}</ref> Amendments to the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Act 1995 came into effect on 1 January 2013 to allow video games to receive the adults only rating.<ref name=":2" /> Games that were refused classification prior to 1 January 2013 can be designated an R18+ rating and made available for sale in Australia if the publisher of the game applies for re-classification and pays a fee.<ref>{{cite news|title= Gamers fume as states delay lifting ban on R 18+ video games|work= [[The Age]]|date=|url=http://www.theage.com.au/digital-life/games/gamers-fume-as-states-delay-lifting-ban-on-r-18-video-games-20101210-18sih.html#ixzz1LJy0OYIP|accessdate=2011-05-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title= ACT moves on classifying R18+ video games|work= [[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]]|date=|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2011/04/29/3203835.htm|accessdate=2011-05-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title= Banned: the absurdity of Australia's game rating regime|work= [[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]]|date=|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2008/07/31/2319787.htm|accessdate=2011-05-03}}</ref>
Games can still be refused classification and banned from sale if they depict, express or otherwise deal with matters of sex, drug misuse or addiction, crime, cruelty, violence or revolting or abhorrent phenomena in such a way that they offend against the standards of morality, decency and propriety generally accepted by reasonable adults to the extent that they should not be classified.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.classification.gov.au/Guidelines/Pages/RC.aspx|title=RC {{!}} Australian Classification|website=www.classification.gov.au|language=en-au|access-date=2017-06-01}}</ref>
Notable video games that have been refused classification since the introduction of an R18+ for video games include: [[Saints Row IV]], [[South Park: The Stick of Truth]], [[Hotline Miami 2: Wrong Number]] and [[Outlast 2]].<ref name=":0" />
Material which is refused classification is put on the [[Australian Customs and Border Protection Service]] list of prohibited items. Any copies of these games found at the border will be seized, and its recipient, depending on the number of copies being imported may receive up to AUD$110,000 in fines.<ref name="Kozanecki">{{cite web|first=James|last=Kozanecki|date=2011-03-15|title=Aussie customs to seize Mortal Kombat imports|url=http://au.gamespot.com/pages/news/story.php?sid=6303984|publisher=Gamespot|accessdate=2011-03-15|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110319160323/http://au.gamespot.com/pages/news/story.php?sid=6303984|archive-date=2011-03-19|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
An individual is allowed to own, use, access or create Refused Classification items, including games (with the exception of Western Australia). But a Refused Classification rating means that the created item is illegal to sell within Australia.
==See also== *[[:Category:Video game companies of Australia]]
== References == {{Reflist|2}}
== External links == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20140228152127/http://www.acmi.net.au/global/docs/games_history_australia.pdf Australian Centre for the Moving Image – History of Game Development in Australia]
{{History of video games}}
[[Category:Video gaming by country|Australia]] [[Category:Video gaming in Australia| ]] [[Category:Science and technology in Australia]]

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contribs/68.146.85.121|68.146.85.121]] ([[User talk:68.146.85.121|talk]]) to last version by CambridgeBayWeather
revision.text:
[[File:Alaskan dancers.jpg|thumb|250px|Alaska Native dance troupe with skirtled Kuskokwim style [[kuspuk]] at the [[University of Alaska Museum of the North]].]] [[File:Alaska Native dancer wearing kuspuk.jpg|thumb|250px|Yup'ik dancer from [[Inu-Yupiaq]] dance group performing in a kuspuk]]
'''Yup'ik dancing''' (or '''dance''') or '''Yuraq''', also '''Yuraqing''' ([[Central Alaskan Yup'ik language|Yup'ik]] ''yuraq'' {{IPA|/juʁaq/}} <small>sg</small> ''yurak'' <small>dual</small> ''yurat'' <small>pl</small>) is a traditional [[Eskimo]] style [[dancing]] form usually performed to songs in Yup'ik, with dances choreographed for specific songs which the [[Central Alaskan Yup'ik people|Yup'ik]] people of southwestern [[Alaska]]. Also known as '''Cup'ik dance''' for the [[Chevak Cup’ik language|Chevak Cup'ik]] dialect speaking Eskimos of [[Chevak, Alaska|Chevak]] and '''Cup'ig dance''' for the [[Nunivak Cup'ig language|Nunivak Cup'ig]] dialect speaking Eskimos of [[Nunivak Island]]. Yup'ik dancing is set up in a very specific and cultural format. Typically, the men are in the front, kneeling and the women stand in the back. The drummers are in the very back of the dance group. Dance is the heart of Yup’ik spiritual and social life. Every song has a story behind it and some songs is either about hunting or berry picking. Some songs could be about sports or other things that don't really relate to hunting. Traditional dancing in the [[qasgiq]] is a communal activity in Yup’ik tradition. The [[Yup'ik masks|mask]] (''kegginaquq'') was a central element in Yup'ik ceremonial dancing.<ref name="Emilyjohnson">[[Emily Johnson]] (1998), [http://jashm.press.illinois.edu/9.3/9-3Yupik_Johnson131-149.pdf “Yup'ik Dance: Old and New,”] ''The Journal for the Anthropological Study of Human Movement'', Vol. 9, No. 3. pp. 131-149</ref>
Eskimo dancing of their ancestors was [[Ban (law)|banned]] by [[Mission (Christianity)|Christian missionaries]] in the late 19th century as ''primitive idolatry''. After a century, [[Cama-i]] dance festival is a cultural celebration that started in the mid 1980s with a goal to gather outlying village Eskimo dancers to share their music and dances. There are now many dance groups who perform Eskimo dances in Alaska. Most popular activity in the Yup'ik-speaking Eskimo area is rediscovered Yup'ik dancing.
==Eskimo dancing== Both Yup'ik and [[Iñupiaq]] dancing are also known as '''Eskimo dancing''' or '''Eskimo dance''' in Alaska.
The most obvious ways in which the Eskimo dancing of northwestern Alaska (known as '''Iñupiaq style Eskimo dance''') differs from that of southwestern Alaska (known as '''Yup'ik style Eskimo dance''') are in: the beating of the frame-drum from below, rather than from above; the standing, rather than the kneeling, of the male dancers; the very small use of decorative dance fans (''de rigueur'' in the south); and the considerable musical ceremonialism that still survives (which never developed as much in the south and southwest of Alaska, although it certainly existed there).<ref name="refThomasmusic">Thomas F. Johnston (1976), [http://pubs.aina.ucalgary.ca/arctic/Arctic29-1-7.pdf The Eskimo Songs of Northwestern Alaska]. ''Arctic'', Vol 29, No 1 (1976), pp. 7-19</ref>
==Yuraryaraq== ''Yuraryaraq'' <small>sg</small> ''Yuraryarat'' <small>pl</small> (lit. "way[s] of dancing") or ''Yupiit Yuraryarait'' (lit. "Yup'ik ways of dancing") embrace six fundamental key entities identified as ''ciuliat'' (ancestors), ''angalkuut'' (shamans), ''cauyaq'' (drum), ''yuaruciyaraq'' (song structures), ''yurarcuutet'' (regalia) and ''yurarvik'' (dance location).<ref name="Theresaarevgaq">Theresa Arevgaq John (2010). ''[http://ankn.uaf.edu/Curriculum/PhD_Projects/Arevgaq/Yuraryaraput_Kangiit-llu.pdf Yuraryararput Kangiit-llu: Our Ways of Dance and Their Meanings]''. University of Alaska Fairbanks. Fairbanks, Alaska.</ref>
The [[ancestor]]s (''ciuliaq'' <small>sg</small> ''ciuliat'' <small>pl</small>, ''ciuliaput'' "our ancestors") are regarded with respect and believed to be part of the living in Yup'ik [[epistemology]].<ref name="Theresaarevgaq"/>
The [[Angakkuq|shaman]] (''angalkuq'' <small>sg</small> ''angalkuk'' <small>dual</small> ''angalkut'' <small>pl</small>) played a functional role in dance. The role of shaman as the primary leader, petitioner, and a trans-mediator between the human and non-human spiritual worlds in association with music, dance, and masks. The shaman’s professional responsibility was to enact ancient forms of prayers to request for the survival needs of the people. The specified masks depicted survival essentials requested in ceremonies.<ref name="Theresaarevgaq"/> Shamans often carved the symbolic masks that were vital to many Yup'ik ceremonial dances and this masks represented spirits that the shaman saw during visions.<ref name="Ahniemarie">Ahnie Marie Al'aq David Litecky (2011). [http://etd.lib.umt.edu/theses/available/etd-05102011-142458/unrestricted/Litecky_Ahnie_Thesis.pdf ''The Dwellers Between: Yup'ik Shamans and Cultural Change in Western Alaska''] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141223125104/http://etd.lib.umt.edu/theses/available/etd-05102011-142458/unrestricted/Litecky_Ahnie_Thesis.pdf |date=December 23, 2014 }}. The University of Montana</ref> ''Nepcetat'' (powerful ceremonial masks) were empowered by shamans. Shamans wearing masks of bearded seal, moose, wolf, eagle, beaver, fish, and the north wind were accompanied with drums and music.<ref name="Theresaarevgaq"/>
[[File:Drummer Nunivak Curtis LOC.JPG|thumb|left|250px|[[Nunivak Cup’ig language|Nunivak Cup’ig]] playing a very large drum in 1927 by [[Edward S Curtis]].]] The [[drum]] (''cauyaq'' <small>sg</small> ''cauyak'' <small>dual</small> ''cauyat'' <small>pl</small>) is only instrument in yuraryaraq. Drum that is accompanied with a [[drum stick]] (''cauyaun'', ''mumeq'', ''mengruq''). The drum is made with a round [[bentwood]] frame crafted with a designed handle. Traditionally, the [[drumskin]] (''eciq'' or ''cauyam ecia'') was made out of fine mammal stomach lining. The drum was to be treated with respect and used for ceremonial purposes.<ref name="Theresaarevgaq"/> The Yup'ik calendar clearly marks the seasons and seasonal rounds of activity. The November (''Cauyarvik'' in Nelson Island dialect, ''Causarvik'' in Kotlik dialect, lit. "place for drumming”) is the time for drumming.<ref>Nita Y. Rearden (2013), [http://www.alaskateacherresources.org/large_files/Calendar-12month-Yupik-byNitaRearden.pdf Calendar Sample of Kotlik]</ref>
The [[Song structure (popular music)|song structures]] (''yuaruciyaraq'' <small>sg</small>) in ceremonies are composed and choreographed differently. The ceremonies are accompanied with music and must adhere to specific composition formalities as practiced by Yup’ik ancestors. This musical forms of songs are warm-up chorus (''ayakata’aryaraq''), chorus (''agnera''), first verse (''apalluan ciuqlia''), voiceless motion (''cauyarialnguq''), second verse (''apalluan kinguqlia''), encore (''pamyua'').<ref name="Theresaarevgaq"/>
[[File:Ceremonial mask wearer Nunivak Curtis LOC.JPG|thumb|250px|A man wearing a ceremonial [[Yup'ik masks|mask]] of the Nunivak Cup’ig style in 1927 by Edward S Curtis.]]
The dance [[regalia]] (''yurarcuun'' <small>sg</small> ''yurarcuutek'' <small>dual</small> ''yurarcuutet'' <small>pl</small>) includes ''qaliq'' (fancy fur parka), ''nasqurrun'' (wolf/wolverine/caribou beaded headdress), ''uyamik'' (beaded necklaces), ''tegumiak'' (finger mask or woven grass caribou dance fans), ''piluguuk'' (decorated boots), and ivory/beaded earrings. Men wear round wooden fans with waterfowl or owl feathers. Today, both female and male dancers wear designed [[qaspeq]] (hand-sewn calico pullover clothing).<ref name="Theresaarevgaq"/>
Dance [[Yup'ik masks|mask]] (''kegginaquq'' <small>sg</small> ''kegginaquk'' <small>dual</small> ''kegginaqut'' <small>pl</small>) was a central element in Yup'ik ceremonial dancing.
Dance fans or finger masks or maskettes (''tegumiaq'' <small>sg</small> ''tegumiak'' <small>dual</small> ''tegumiat'' <small>pl</small>): Hand-held fans accentuate the fluid movements of a dancer’s arms. They were used in traditional winter ceremonies and continue as part of contemporary Yup’ik dance regalia. Men’s fans, like this pair, have feathers inserted into wooden hoops.<ref>[http://alaska.si.edu/record.asp?id=216 Alaska Native Collections : tegumiak “pair of dance fans”]</ref>
Dance headdress (''nasqurrun'' <small>sg</small> ''nasqurrutek'' <small>dual</small> ''nasqurrutet'' <small>pl</small>): Women wore similar headdresses, which remain a part of modern Yup’ik dance regalia for both sexes.<ref>[http://alaska.si.edu/record.asp?id=220 Alaska Native Collections : nasqurrun “dance headdress”]</ref>
The dance location (''yurarvik'' <small>sg</small> ''yurarviik'' <small>dual</small> ''yurarviit'' <small>pl</small> lit. "place for dancing”). The [[qasgiq]] is where people danced in ancient times.<ref name="Theresaarevgaq"/> The qasgiq, was the community center for ceremonies and festivals which included singing, dancing, and storytelling.
==Types== The '''Yuraq''' (''yuraq'' <small>sg</small> ''yurak'' <small>dual</small> ''yurat'' <small>pl</small>) is use generic term for Yup'ik/Cup’ik regular dance. Also, yuraq is concerned with animal behaviour and hunting of animals, or with ridicule of individuals (ranging from affectionate teasing to punishing public embarrassment).<ref name="Theresaarevgaq"/> But, use for inherited dance is '''Yurapik''' or '''Yurapiaq''' (''yurapiaq ~ yurapik'' <small>sg</small> ''yurapiit'' <small>pl</small>, lit. "real dance") and yurapik long story dance performed by women,<ref name="Agayuliyararpu">[[Ann Fienup-Riordan|Fienup-Riordan, Ann]] (1996). ''The Living Tradition of Yup'ik Masks: Agayuliyararput (Our Way of Making Prayer)''. Seattle, WA: University of Washington Press.</ref> or is a dance style that relates to dance sequences that have no associated song [and] are owned by individuals and passed down through family lines.<ref name="Theresaarevgaq"/>
Types of dances are ''nangercelluku'' (first dances), ''yagirat'' (motions dances), ''cukaqautet'' (fast beat dances), ''ciuqitet'' (contemporary dances), ''ingulautet'' (slow dances).<ref name="Theresaarevgaq"/> Rhythmic dances combined distinct gestures, story-telling, songs and the use of drums and masks. There were six styles of yuraq: ''arula'' dances consisting of yuraq, verse and chorus; ''yurapiat'' (storytelling dances); ''ingula'' dances, which were slow, oldstyle dances performed by women following berry harvests; ''pualla'' dances, primarily performed by men; ''yurat'' done to ''taitnauq'' songs; and ''telciqata'arcutet'', or proper entrance dances.<ref name="Emilyjohnson"/>
==Banning of dancing== The reasons of the discrediting of traditional native dances are the effects of social changes that came about in the late 19th century as a result of [[North American fur trade|fur trade]], [[epidemics]], and [[Mission (Christianity)|missionary]] activity.<ref name="Emilyjohnson"/> Along with the expansion of Europeans and Americans into Alaska were accompanying hardships for the indigenous people: epidemic diseases, strong Christian missionary activities, and western educational policies such as English language-only rules.<ref>Maria Shaa Tlaa Williams (2005) {She is an [[ethnomusicologist]] from the [[Tlingit]] nation}. [http://www.nps.gov/akso/nature/science/ak_park_science/PDF/2005Vol4-1/williams.pdf To dance is to be: heritage preservation in the 21st century]. in ''Alaska Park Science'', Vol 4-1.</ref> Ancestral Eskimo dancing and non-Christian [[Festival|festivities]], traditional ceremonies, and [[Shamanism among Eskimo peoples|shamanistic]] rites were discouraged or even demonized and [[Ban (law)|banned]] by Christian missionaries in the late 19th century as ''primitive idolatry''. Shamanistic rituals are no longer practiced, although some elders have information about these rites. Song and dance have remained.<ref>[http://alaska.si.edu/culture_inupiaq.asp?subculture=Arctic%20Coast&continue=1 Alaska Native Collections : Jana Harcharek, Iñupiaq]</ref> The [[Moravian Church in North America|Moravian Church]] had banned dancing from the villages.<ref>Jerry Lipka (1998) with Gerald V. Mohatt and the Ciulistet group. ''[https://books.google.com.tr/books?id=o8alAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA178&lpg=PA178&dq=%22Yup%27ik+dancing%22&source=bl&ots=2-4ns-O8Vl&sig=KRI0aHgYXlIkDpglE_j41wSvYVI&hl=tr&sa=X&ei=JBNVVMGMEc2S7Ab7tICQBw&ved=0CFIQ6AEwBw#v=onepage&q=%22Yup%27ik%20dancing%22&f=false Transforming the Culture of Schools: Yup’ik Eskimo Examples]''</ref> Yuraq dancing feasts between villages in the [[King Salmon, Alaska|King Salmon]] and [[Naknek, Alaska|Naknek]] region were forbidden by [[Orthodox Church in America|Russian Orthodox]] priests as of 1933.<ref>Kerry D. Feldman (1978), Occupancy and Use of Naknek Area From Late 19th Century. Unpublished Manuscript, on file Department of Anthropology, University of Alaska Anchorage.</ref><ref>Feldman, Kerry D (2001), [http://www.uaa.alaska.edu/anthropology/people/upload/King_Salmon.pdf “Ethnohistory and the IRA Tribal Status Application of King Salmon Natives, Alaska”], ''Alaska Journal of Anthropology'' 1 (1):100 –117.</ref> Dancing as part of Yup'ik feasts no longer existed as [[Jesuit missionaries]] forbade it at the end of the 19th century. Many of these spiritual ceremonies, such as the ''Agayuyaraq'', an intervillage ceremony associated with the performance of masked dances usually at the end of the winter season, were abandoned.<ref name="Nuttall2005">{{cite book|last=Nuttall|first=Mark|title=Encyclopedia of the Arctic: A-F|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LcucDSk4w3YC&pg=PA1461|accessdate=2014-04-11|year=2005|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-57958-436-8|page=348}}</ref> Masked dances and the Kelek (masquerade) dances were among the first to be removed from Yup'ik practice. Because of their highly spiritual content, dances were considered dangerous by missionaries who called them "heathen idol worship, devil's frolic and black art".<ref name="Emilyjohnson"/>
==Dance festivals== There are now many dance groups who perform Eskimo dances in Alaska. There are many performances and festivals, however, that are more traditional in their role. Masked dances especially have served as a strong reminder of the connection to the worlds of animals and spirits. Dances embody the Yup'ik conception of the world. The beliefs that stem from this conception are the models by which Yup'iks live. Today, a dance festival, both in preparation and the actual event, consumes an entire village with its significance, just as it did in pre-contact times.<ref name="Emilyjohnson"/>
The first Yup'ik [[dance festival]] is [[Yupiit Yuraryarait]] (lit. "Yup'ik ways of dancing") started in 1982 at [[St. Mary's, Alaska|St. Mary's]] (''Negeqliq''), fostering a revival of the traditions of the Yup’ik people.<ref>https://www.nlm.nih.gov/nativevoices/timeline/552.html?tribe=Yup%27ik</ref> Concerned about the survival of Yup’ik cultural heritage, the Negeqliq first brought together artists where traditional dancing was still practiced to participate in a festival designed to pass on dance traditions to younger generations. Nine villages in [[Yukon–Kuskokwim Delta]] came to that intervillage festival. The success of that event stimulated the creation of dance festivals throughout the lower Yukon River region.<ref>Elizabeth Peterson (1996), ''[http://arts.gov/sites/default/files/Changing-Faces-of-Tradition.pdf The changing faces of tradition: a report on the golk and traditional arts in the United States]''. National Endowment for the Arts</ref><ref>Tim Troll (2008), [http://www.adn.com/article/20080511/remembering-man-who-helped-revive-yupik-dancing Remembering the man who helped revive Yup'ik dancing]. ''Alaska Dispatch News'', May 11, 2008</ref> The Yupiit Yuraryarait is a dance festival that is now held every three or four years.<ref name="Emilyjohnson"/>
The second Yup'ik dance festival is [[Cama-i]] (lit. "hello; greetings; pleased to meet you; good to see you again") started in 1984 in [[Bethel, Alaska|Bethel]] (''Mamterilleq''). Traditional dancers from all over Alaska and beyond participate every March in the Cama-i dance festival. Bethel is unique in the region in having an astounding diversity of cultures, including a large contingent of Koreans. The Cama-i dance festival, an annual event in Bethel in the spring, hosts [[Alaska Native]] dancers from all over the state as well as [[Koreans|Korean]] and [[Japanese people|Japanese]] dancers, and dancers from other regions of the world and the nation.<ref>http://camai.org/</ref><ref>Delena Norris-Tull (1999 ). [http://ankn.uaf.edu/curriculum/Yupiaq/DelenaNorrisTull/aKuskokwim%20Delta.htm Introduction to the Kuskokwim Delta]. University of Alaska Fairbanks, Fairbanks, Alaska.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://kyuk.org/cama-i-dance-festival/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=November 2, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150325194201/http://kyuk.org/cama-i-dance-festival/ |archivedate=March 25, 2015 }}</ref>
